reviewText: It was 1 on 1... I was scared.\n\nHe knew where I was and I knew where he was. We waited, for two whole minutes across the hall from one another while both teams watched. reviewText:
I have played Battlefield 2, 3, 4.
I have played Insurgency.
I have played Far Cry 1/2/3/4.
I have played Counter-Strike Global Offensive.
I have played various other shooters.

But this game? THIS IS JUST AWESOME!

Imagine Battlefield 3 and his brother Battlefield 4 having a threesome with Insurgency. Pregnant (from 1 of the 2 but who cares don't ruin my story!). Baby gets older. Gets kids with Far Cry 1. Cheats with FC2,FC3 and FC4. More kids. All of them get kids with CS:GO.

One of those kids is a miracle.

It's the tension of Insurgency.
The fun of Battlefield.
The beauty of Far Cry.
The tactical aspect of Counter-Strike.
And the teamplay of Squad. (Didn't mention that one... WHO CHEATED WITH SQUAD!?)

Rainbow Six Siege.

Worth every single penny.

And patience for updates regarding the matchmaking system which let us down several times. Sigh.

Hey, just BUY IT!

reviewText:
This game encourages mic communication so much, that it will force enable your mic to always be on, even if you have it disabled. Causing everyone in the game to hear whatever you say, even if it was only meant for your friends over Skype.

GG. No privacy out of 10.

This has been fixed. Kinda. It still happens to other people on occasion.

This game's servers are so powerful, that they can manage to keep 10 players connected flawlessly with next-to-no lag in an endless loading screen that pops up 80% of the time when joining a match. Unable to exit, all you can do is open task manager. On the plus side, you can still talk to everyone while all of you chill in purgatory. So essentially, Uplay made a group Omeggle with the rare off-chance of actually playing a game.

reviewText:
The deepest tactical shooter I've played in my life. Every decision made has put gameplay over realism and tradition in shooters, and they've got a masterpiece to show for it. It's as simple and elegant as chess with the same learning curve as you discover new combinations, strategies, and counter-strategies.

If you like hardcore shooters, do not miss this game, and do not pass judgment lightly. If you're looking for the Unreal Tournament or Call of Duty experience, this is not for you.


Edit:
In response to 0.1 hours on record comment. I played alpha, both closed betas and their preceding technical tests, got a few rounds in during Siege Day in LA, and spent a week at Ubisoft Montreal playing the game and giving feedback on behalf of the community. To verify this, you're welcome to watch the Road to Montreal" livestream footage on YouTube; I'm "geofurb" in those matches. I'm probably one of the most experienced players at the moment

reviewText:
This game is like anal , hard in the beginning
but you get a lot of pleasure once you get used to it.


------------------------------------------------------
It's tough, skill-focused, smart and notable game.

if you're a fan of stories and set-pieces rather than co-op and competitive online play, this really isn't the Rainbow Six you're looking for.

Like CS, R6S  is all about deadly skills, snap reactions, strong map strategy and adaptability, and when one mistake can leave you dead and out of the round, you really has better pay attention and think before you move.

Its sad that the campaign isn't that long , but its teaches you the basics and
each of them has their difficulties so you will need your sweet time and effort.

Besides the campaign you got casual , competive and terrorist hunt
Casual is just a 5vs5 casual match , competive a 5 vs 5 competive match.
The matchmaking isn't perfect , e.g : sitting in a team like this : lv20 , lv 69, lv89 , 100+
And terrorist hunt is where you play with a 5 man team to play against bots , its sounds easy but without real teamwork and strategy you are dead. Ripperino

The grafics aren't bad , but here all the love and work has gone into the game's destructible detail, as gunfire and explosions tear great chunks out of stud walls and furniture, and as breach charges shatter tough stone walls ectr
I don't think there are a lot of games around that put that much details in it :)

The community is overall positive , most of the time you will get fun and polite teammates.
Beware though there are always ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s.

I recommend buying this when its on sale.

Thank you for taking your time to read this !
Leaving a thumb up and a comment would be a great help !

reviewText:
Rainbow Six is back with a new title and it's only multiplayer, but will you want to play it ?

Rainbow Six Siege the new game in the Rainbow Six series. This game rose up from the ashes of what once was Rainbow Six Patriots.

The game is set in current times where the fight against terrorism is full blown out. Terrorist are conducting massive attacks around the world and you play as either the terrorists or the rainbow unit which consists of worldwide response units.

As stated before the game has no story whatsoever. The only thing you can do solo is a situation mode which teaches you the basics of the game and the incredibly fun Terrorist Hunt mode. The game has one story mission which is online only which tasks you to go to a US college and defuse a toxic bomb, the mission is notable because it obscures your vision with toxic gas and you need to work as a team to defuse the bombs, cause the mission is really difficult.

The AI for solo mode is not stupid so you won't be able to Rambo the entire map. You will have to be smart with your actions since the AI is pretty smart. They change up they're routes and will try to flank you and rush you any chance they get, they're aim is pretty good as well.

Now for the reason you might want to buy the game, THE PVP.

Trust me when I say this, the game is no joke. This game is incredibly difficult and doesn't hold your hand. You will need to work as a team if you want to win. A well placed shot will take you out and a well planned attack might earn you a sweet victory.

The game suits many play styles, from a support who helps out teammates in the field, to a pyromaniac who likes to blow up everything in sight. You will definitely find an operator that suits you the best.

Even though there's not many maps, each map is very dynamic. It's big enough for you to defend, but no matter what remember, you are never safe. You can destroy almost every wall, ceiling or floor so you never feel safe no matter how good your defenses are.

The game has one major flaw and that's the horrible servers. The servers are way too unpredictable. At one moment they work fine, the other they won't give you any money or won't even load you to the game. Ubisoft stated that they are working on fixing this issue so I trust them to get it sorted out.

The game is optimised incredibly well. It runs at 60 fps maxed out. If you have a high end PC you will have no trouble running this game.

In the end do I recommend the game ? Yes I do. I do suggest at the very least waiting for the server issue to be fixed and you have one of the best squad based games ever made. Get a few friends for the ride and you have one incredible game on your hands.

Final Rating:
9/10 - A must own (after servers are fixed)

If you liked this review please consider giving it a thumbs up and if you disliked post in the comments on what you disliked about the review.

For more reviews follow Snort's Review curator page here - follow for regular updates on reviews for other games!

reviewText:
Never had my heart beat so fast while playing video games than this. 8/10

Edit*

Since my review came op as one of the most helpful i've decided to expand it with some details

Rainbow six siege is mainly about two teams fighting agaisnt each other in a FPS counter terrorism world, one team as the defenders (Terrorists) other team as attackers (Counter-terrorits). The special thing about this game is the strategi and the destruction of the maps.

every game can feel very different, because both teams has a fair amount of characters to choose from who all has one special abililty. The destruction is a very big factor why i think the game is great, it gives it a LOT of replayability. There are so many different ways to defend a point or even to attack one. the teamplay and strategi is also important, your team will have a WAY higher chance of winning if you all communicate and plan your attacks.

The singleplayer isnt as great as the other rainbow games, there are basically two ways of playing singleplayer, one is to play lonewolf in terrorist hunt, terrorist hunt is your team or your self agaisnt AI. The other way is to play situations which are premade lonewolf maps with AI. there is no campaign.

The design of the game is really MLG as i would call it, all the characters doesnt really look like counter-terrorist units. which isnt a bad thing it just kinda takes the imersion away. otherwise the map is just trying to simulate the real world, which it does nicely. The graphics runs well on my computer with the highest settings.

The gun play and gameplay is close to perfect (If you ask me). its nothing like arma 3 but it has a very good feel to it, and sometimes even so much that i feel like i'm a SWAT solider breaching into a building ;D. There are sometimes where its kinda unrealistic but its nothing close to a problem.

The commuinity i have played with is nice, they play toghter, work togther and most importantly they communicate (Have had some games with people that didnt work togther at all but it doesnt ruin it)

(Nothing about the game it self) I just want to add that ubisoft have made a lot of ♥♥♥♥♥♥ stuff like AAC Unity, i'm very happy how this turned out since it was one of my childhood games. but that doesnt mean that ubisoft are the good guys" they still use Uplay

reviewText:
I've got probably 300 hours in this game if you count both betas.  I will have many, many more.

This is the Game of the Year for me.  Competing with The Witcher 3 in my personal opinion.

This is the only first person shooter that has been able to take my attention away from counterstrike.... in twelve years.

The potential for teamplay is amazing.  The mechanics are beautiful and solid.  The game is optimized beyond belief, running at a constant 90-120 fps on my outdated, crappy system.

There is a character for (almost) every type of player.

This is not a casual game.

I have absolutely no complaints.

Cheers.

AMD FX 8320 with 8 gigs of ram
Radeon R9 280X  (2048 mb) GDDR5

reviewText:
A tactical shooter centered around either attacking or defending a structure may not sound unique or new, but Rainbow Six: Siege really takes that idea and expands on it in amazing ways.

RS:S is a continuation of Tom Clancy's Rainbow Six saga and the story is much of the same you'd expect in a game like this, but it does the job: an international terror group is attempting to cause as much destruction as possible for reasons unknown and you're part of an elite counter-terror team tasked with stopping them. You can get your bearings with the tutorials and after that, there are a number of singleplayer missions that expand on the game's features. Both the tutorials and singleplayer missions are invaluable to learning the game and the various maps that you'll encounter in multiplayer. You can jump into multiplayer at anytime, but it's not advised to do that right off the bat.

The loadout available to you in multiplayer is based off of the Operator you choose to play as - unique characters unlocked with Renown, a form of game currency that you earn by completing the tutorials, singleplayer missions, or multiplayer matches and specific objectives and actions between the three of them. There is a microtransaction alternative to Renown points, but worry not: you earn more than enough Renown points through regular gameplay. Each individual Operator also has a special piece of equipment unique to them and there's enough variety to make them all useful in their own ways. You can also play as the generic Recruit character with access to default equipment.

As mentioned before, RS:S is centered around defending or attacking a structure with the aim to disarm bombs, rescue hostages, or simply kill the opposing team. However, what makes RS:S special is the means and methods the game provides to you in order to carry out these objectives. Nearly everything in the game's environment can be destroyed or damaged in some way, creating endless tactical scenarios: you can destroy the ceiling to swoop in on an enemy team, trade fire between destructable walls, breach doorways and destroy barricades obstructing your path, deploy ground-based drones to suss out enemy positions - the possibilities are endless. On the flip side, the defending team can set up a plethora of traps, barricades, and other obstructions to impede the other side, all the while having access to various surveillance methods to keep a close eye on the going-ons of their base. The unique Operator characters on either team make use of EMP grenades, sticky gas bombs, deployable manned turrets, heartbeat detectors and much more. But remember, slow and methodical is  not  how you want to play this game - reminiscent of real life breaching tactics, you're expected to be fast and decisive!

The environment is the true star of RS:S. It can mean either life or death depending on how a team decides to use it and can be shaped to each individual players' whims, and that is what makes RS:S special.

Absolutely recommended.

reviewText:
Review for Australian and New Zealand regionsHere are my thoughts, after spending over 250 hours in Rainbow Six Siege, inclusive of both Closed and Open Beta as well as live. I will be focusing on my review primarily from my experiences playing in the Australian/New Zealand region, and much of the review will be focused around the month after initial launch as well as the three patches prior to launch, aimed at fixing some of the issues faced within the game. This review has been updated one week after the February patch to reflect the changes seen in the recent Black Ice DLC release.

What is the gameplay like?I love strategy, and when you combine that in a first person shooter, it's even better. The gameplay is dynamic and unique, with each round within a match offering a wide variety of plays that can be moulded by your team to accommodate the situation. Being generally accustomed to the usual first person shooters like Battlefield and Counter-Strike, I found R6S to be refreshing and very entertaining. Combining the dynamic environments of Battlefield's Frostbite-like destruction and the slower paced, methodical strategy and tactics needed for competitive Counter-Strike makes for an awesome first person shooter experience.

How is the class balance?Each operator feels unique, balanced and appropriately lethal when used in the right situation and coordinated well with other teammates. Each operator fills a specific role on the team and there is generally an appropriate counter for each operator, both on the attacking and defending teams. This helps to contribute to the overall balance of each round. Strategising a team composition is the key to countering the opposing team. Combining the unique skillset that each operator provides as well as the fortification and destruction mechanics of R6S makes for some very entertaining and exhilarating gameplay. More operators, as well as maps will be added for free (yes, free!) in upcoming DLCs, adding more potential for amazing, dynamic gameplay.

What state is the game currently in for Australian and New Zealand players?In my opinion, from experiences so far; the game is relatively more stable than it was in the past few months. Previously, there were many issues that would detract from the overall gameplay experience. There are still major issues that do need to be worked on by Ubisoft, but with the release of the recent DLC (Black Ice), my gameplay and experiences have been significantly smoother and more enjoyable as a whole. I will state any issues below and further elaborate:
There was a major issue with latency and hit registration that persisted from CB/OB all the way onto the live release. This continued on for two months with Ubisoft prioritising it as one of the major issues that needed to be resolved. They did this by pumping out a number of patches within a span of two months which helped to alleviate the problems players were experiencing. There was still an occasional situation where players were running around with 200+ ping, however this was due to them being from a region other than AU/NZ. This caused the usual peeker’s advantage issue that is prevalent in some FPS games to be more significant than it should have been. Poor latency and server connections also caused some situations where players would die behind cover or some other similar, yet unexplainable circumstances. I am glad to say that as of February 2016, the latency and rubber-banding has now been resolved in my eyes, and from my experiences playing prior to the Black Ice DLC release.

Previously AU/NZ players would have difficulty finding ranked games as the majority of the Oceanic community seemed to stray away from ranked matches. This was due to the previously poor latency and server connection issues. Ranked queues still take significantly longer than casual queues, however I think that this issue will be improved as more players re-join to try out the new DLC and discover that there are less latency/connection issues.

From what I’ve seen playing in casual matches, there are still a significant amount of players randomly connecting from matches, or taking longer to load, which leaves them unable to choose an operator or not being able to connect at all. This issue is still causing unbalanced matches for 5v5, 4v3, 5v3, etc. and therefore giving their team a disadvantage against their opponents.

I previously mentioned in my review that there were a decent amount of players that were not willing to communicate, whether through the team chat, or through voice communication. In a game such as R6:S, communication is paramount to coordinate effective strategies and tactics. Players are still running off solo and attempting to breach alone, and will more often than not get picked off and killed by the defenders. This is still an issue that I don’t think can really be resolved.

In my experience, there seems to be quite a bit of trolling/stubbornness coming from players who do decide to go off solo and not work together with the rest of the team. I can understand that some players just want to play a casual game of R6S and not really be fussed about communicating with the rest of their team, leaving the strategy to ranked games. However sometimes this can lead to miscommunication, or lack of communication, where players lack the appropriate intel to make informed decisions in a game that can be quite punishing. This can be disheartening for players that are less experienced in the game, be a huge turn-off and might push away some players.

There is also the odd occasion when a player will decide to team kill, or assassinate the hostage which is quite disappointing given the game's strong emphasis on teamwork and communication. This however might only apply to the AU/NZ player base as I have heard positive comments about strong communication and teamwork from players in other regions.
If you do decide to purchase this game, I strongly urge to you to have a working microphone ready to use as this game is so much more fun when players actively communicate together to win matches. Also, please be prepared to communicate, it really makes a difference!

Should you buy Rainbow Six: Siege?Yes and no. Were it not for the issues highlighted above, this would be a glowing review and high recommendation for R6S. The release of the Black Ice DLC as well as the recent February patch has shone some positive light on the title, which may sway some readers to purchase this game. However, my initial verdict from my previous review still stands.

The gameplay itself is very addictive and rewarding if played correctly. I will not deny that some if not all of the issues will detract from the overall gaming experience such as the disconnections, latency issues, hit registration and the occasional uncooperative player(s). As it stands, I can only tentatively recommend this game to you.

If you are really interested in this game and the franchise, enticed by the unique gameplay and are willing to put up with some of these slight nuisances and wait till Ubisoft resolves them - then yes. The majority of games that are completed without any hiccups will be extremely exhilarating. The sense of accomplishment felt when collaborating with random players to win a match through strong teamwork and communication is unparalleled for a game of this genre.

On the other hand, if you are not ready to put up with the issues mentioned, no. Hold out until the game improves in a few weeks/months after the latest DLC release and then please give it another shot.

----------

reviewText:
Tom Clancy's Rainbow Six Siege honest review

PROS
+Competative multiplayer-based combat
+Fun yet challenging side-ops
+Completable challenges
+Buyable 'operators'
+Customizable weaponry
+Intriquite map design
+Addicting

CONS
-Some glitched lobbies, soon to be fixed
-Pre-game lag (probably just my pc)

ABOUT THE OPERATORS

Players may buy operators that suit what they like to do, with currency made by doing online and side-ops. Some operators can place a mounted LMG and has perfect armor. Another can place a barricade that can only be blown up, not shot or melee'd. All operators have very particular abilities, none are remotely the same.

THE TEAMS

You can play as either the terrorists or the counterterrorists with 5 on each team. The police, i'll call of counterterrorists, must breach and clear a selected building with the terrorists inside, either rescuing a hostage, securing some toxic ♥♥♥♥, or defusing a bomb. You can place charges that will detonate and destroy only designated destroyable areas. Other gadgets come with the operaters. The terrorists must fortify their position at once. Place heavy barriers on walls and/or floors to prevent breaching. Also place either a mounted shield or barbed wire (you select which one pre-game), Other gadgets will come with the operators.

GAMEPLAY/GRAPHICS

The game is like no other (maybe a little bit Payday 2). The textures of models and the gunfire feels realistic and fun. Feel free to bring down some settings to make it run faster, as it still will look stunning. The gunfire feels kind of crummy, as your gun goes nuts when you pull the trigger (which is a GOOD thing). This game plays like call of duty but has more less-controlled gunfire.

OVERALL SCORE
9.5/10
A masterpiece by my standareds.

Recommended Purchase: YESDo You Have To Play With Friends To Have A Good Time?: SOMETIMESPurchase Season Pass?: MAYBE (I did...)

Hope this helped :)

Intel(R) Pentium(R) CPU G3258 @ 3.20GHz 3.20 GHz (I know)
NVIDIA GeForce GTX 750 Ti (Pretty sure thats 2 GB)
16.0 GB Memory Ram (4 works just as good)
iBUYPOWER (Manufacturer)
64-bit Operating System, x64-based processor

The Starter Edition is a smart implementation by Ubisoft to get more fresh blood onto the servers because the cost of entry was previously too high for many. reviewText: I bought this game to play with my boyfriend who I live with, we got to play for a few months perfectly fine. We would play with some guys he met online and usually had a full team of 5 players and it was loads of fun, sometimes even having 10 so we would do the custom 5 on 5. LOVED this game. One nice sunny day we woke up early to play and took a break around lunch, when we went back I just kept getting an error code ending in 48. If one of us is logged in, the other can't play at all, no situations, terrorist hunt, nothing. We both opened case files with Ubisoft support and did everything they asked us to do, we did port forwarding, called our ISP, traced packets and many other time consuming tasks. One rep told Youtoast, my bf that we would need a second network. I told this to my rep and he told me that was excessive just to play a game. Well today he told me that they honestly can't say why it was ever working before but not now, that it is not unheard of for multiplayer games to have these issues when 2 users are connecting from the same network, and that after investigating and looking through some things, a second network will MOST LIKELY fix the issue. Had I known this would happen I never would have purchased the game and season pass. I will not be getting a second network just for this game when other multiplayer games let us play together just fine.  If you have siblings, a spouse or roomates who you want to multiplayer with, I would not recommend getting this game.

Basically its great, if a little expensive for what you get.

reviewText:
I put many hours into the beta, and now into the full game and I'm loving every minute of it.

Do not hesitate to buy this game. Overall fantastic gameplay. It feels very smooth and plays very well. Never thought I'd be uttering these words but.... Good job, Ubisoft.

Also, to those experiencing the Steam/Ubisoft Issue, here's a fix:

1. Copy the Steam game folder Tom Clancy's Rainbow Six Siege" located in
C:\Program Files\Steam\steamapps\common\Tom Clancy's Rainbow Six Siege

And copy it somewhere for the time being.


2. Now go back and in steam Right click on the game and Delete Local content (This is why we made a copy)

3. Now place the folder back into the same location it was in and then go into the Folder and open the .EXE and Steam will pop up asking you to reinstall the game.

4.Click Okay and Steam should say something along the lines of "Discovering Existing Files" then your doing it right :)

Now after it is done Click Play and you're all set."

reviewText:
*Notes after Feb 11th 2016 2.1 patch below...*

**Also updated on May 3rd 2016**

I was an open beta player with the pre-purchase of this game. I have 178 hours played at this point in time, and have achieved Platinum rank in Ranked play with a 6.0 Win/Loss ratio. I'm also Level 83 and have everything unlocked for each character, with most top tier skins purchased with renown. These are my credentials in this game, just so you know I'm not speaking out of my behind.

This game is an excellent game, when it works. Key word, when. Tactically, there isn't anything that I know of out there that competes with this title. It's fun, can be high/low paced, and is always very intense. The number of ways to defend and attack are almost limitless and it shows during game play. When you mess up, you're usually punished for it and quickly. So one slip can make the tide of the game completely turn against/for your favour.

However, I did give this a negative review because of the following... This game is terribly inconsistent, and often favours the high latency player. It also has a list horrible of bugs, which people like to exploit often. I have decided that I am uninstalling this game and will not play it until Ubisoft steps up to the plate and actually starts fixing their game. Here's a list of frustrations I have with this title.

Being killed by someone not on your screen. They're 150-200+ ping and have shot you but have not appeared yet, though I have experienced this with lower ping players.

Being unable to vault over a shield because the game doesn't show the [VAULT] on your screen, aka the game forgets to make things vault-able (if that's a word).

Being killed by players during drone phase, in which they're not allowed to escape the building but manage to anyways. They plant C4 on your spawn location, so when you come to life they blow it up.

Being blinded on a shield by random artifacts and patterns on the glass. Not just visible to the victim, but other players being able to see the obstruction on the shield glass.

Being killed by someone you've just shot 3-4x in the head, then notice their health is only down to 75% on the kill cam. Any character with any gun is a 1 shot head shot.

*Fixed Feb 11th 2016, problem since Sept 2015 launch* Being killed by the infamous Kapkan no laser no spike trap hidden inside the wall" glitch

reviewText:
I normally don't write reviews for games, but being an Army Infantry Vet and an AVID CSGO player with 3k+ hours I can safely say.....

This game is ♥♥♥♥ing amazing, it's such a new breath of fresh air within FPSs. It's got the graphics, the gameplay is amazing.

------------

Learning to play from EVERY AGNLE possible is part of the fun here. Hanging upside down in a window and shooting people is amazingly fun, finding people in MM to breach and clear rooms....holy ♥♥♥♥ it brought me back to my Army days. Never have I felt such fun in a new game until now.

The guns have their limits, but aren't exactly the focus. There's not really a huge balance issue with this game either, most of the time when you die you just get out played.

Every gun has their play style, like shotguns? you actually have to play close to walls or windows and not try to shoot medium to far range.

Like to be able to take out enemies who like to peak from afar? Pick up a rifle

Like to run and gun? Well too bad go back to CoD.

Those who complain about the game are normally the CoD players or Silvers out of CSGO who can't actually aim and need to find something to complain about. This is by far one of my new favorite games

reviewText:
I really like this game, and I've played it a lot since it came out, but Ubisoft needs to get their ♥♥♥♥ing ♥♥♥♥ together when it comes to connectivity issues. I'm sick and tired of getting dropped out of ranked matches exclusevily because of Ubisoft's ♥♥♥♥♥♥ servers and that automatically causing me to lose a rank. It's nearly impossible to find a match, ranked or casual, in which 1 or more players don't get dropped and, sometimes, 5 players or more will get dropped at once. Not to mention that it takes for ♥♥♥♥ing ever to find a ranked match, so when you get dropped on the 2nd round after waiting for 10 minutes to find a match, it's pretty frustrating.

This game is a lot of fun, but connectivity issues are ruining the experience for me. I'll give it a negative review until Ubisoft can fix their servers.

EDIT, January 12th, 2016:
The game has been out for well over a month at this point and the connectivity issues persist. Constant drops on casual and ranked games that cause you to get banned and make the rest of the match unfair, matches taking WAY too long to start after all players connect, matches taking way too long to be found and other ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t. The issues aren't as bad as they were on launch, but that's not saying much, since the game was bordering on being unplayable when it came out. To put it in perspective, I would say connectivity issues on this game, as of right now, are hardly acceptable for a Beta, much less for a AAA $60 game that already lacks content. Oh, and it crashes quite frequently, too.

reviewText:
Most fun i have had with a First Person Shooter in years !

Pros
+ solid tactical gameplay - you really have to choose your entry points carefully
+ classes are all fun and exciting to play - each has its own important role
+ microtransactions arent intrusive , as in they only are for weapon skins and a boost of renown ( which is easy to get in the first place )

cons

- some people are jerks and teamkill , but doesnt happen that often . in fact its only happened to me once in 30 hours of gameplay
- killcams are also jacked up and show someone killing you differently from what you saw
- the open mic issue is annoying



overall i would give this game about an 8/10 and is definitly worth your time!!

reviewText:
Alright, I played enough of this game to make a decent review of it.

tldr; get it dirt cheap, and don't bother with their ranked system, try to get friends to play it.


I'm currently in queue for a ranked game and it's been 14 minutes. It must also be the amount of time they spent coding it.

There's 3 way to play this game, PVP Casual, PVP Ranked and PVE.

PVE:
Terrorist Hunt is fun with friends but gets really boring after a while (that's my opinion). Some people really dig it, but I don't anymore.

I'll now talk about the PVP

I played a total of 9 games today:
- 3 of them were 3v5
- 2 of them were with trolls (that killed us and got instakick by the game; too bad Ewplay doesn't give you substitute for them) So I played 1v5 for 2 rounds; the game then went for a 3v5 :)
- 1 with 2 of my premades.
- The other 3 went well.

EDIT: The game i was in queue for was a 3v4.

I used to play Casual and lot and wanted to experience the Ranked system. Turns out it's pure ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥. Played my game through the unranked to Bronze 2-1; with almost the same type of games as mentioned above. I got demoted 5 times in those 10 games.

So the pros:

- The graphics are nice
- the gameplay is fun.
- Strategy and communications are great, too bad people won't use it.

The cons:
- You have to farm the characters or buy them. Top value for the money you paid.
- Customization through in game shop with an excessive amount of farming or money once again.
- Used to have a lot of hackers
- Ranked system sucks super hard.
- You'll play with and against the same guys over and over and over again. For instance, right now, I cancelled my queue a good 10 times just to be matched, again, with the same guys. That trolled our team the previous game.
- There's no AFK kick.
- The netcode will kill you and it must be the only game ever where lagging gives you an advantage
- You can see people through walls sometimes.
- Long queues
- No single player.
- Ewplay
- No point buying Season Pass it's a scam.

The casual mode is the same as ranked, although I find Ranked more challenging; they also make no sense at all. So I'll still play the game but I'm glad Overwatch is coming out later today.

Rainbow Six: Rogue Spear used to be my favorite FPS and one of my first one. I'd like to thank you Ubisoft for destroying everything you touch.

reviewText:
See end for summary.

I really LOVE this game, but I am very objective when I make my reviews.  There are both good and bad things.  Here we go:

Pros+ Combat - there is a good variety of weapons! You can mod them with a few mods, and each one of them has different advantages.
+ Devs - I like the way the game is going at this moment.  What I really care about is that the maps will be free.  I heard the operators will be available to buy with renown as well.  I bought the season pass anyway because I encourage that type of initiative from the devs.  I've never been a fan of microtransactions, but at least they did it only for aeshetic stuff, so I'm okay with that.
+ Game modes - you can play pve and pvp.  Both have different modes.  While in pvp it doesn't make much of a difference because people end up killing each other anyway, in pve it does.
+ Operators - they sound stupid at first, but it's cool to have different operators that do different things...just make sure you tell Fuze not to use the Cluster Charge during an extract hostage...
+ Replayability - sure, there is not a crazy number of maps, but there are different modes and enemies and objectives spawn at different locations, making each time you play it different.
+ Servers - I agree, they were not perfect, but I have seen games releasing much worse.  They also got better over time.

Cons- AI...or AU (Artificial unintelligence) - at times the AI is either incredibly smart (headshots you through walls) or incredibly stupid (walks right into the line of fire).  Could use some fixing.  Also Normal should be easier (for casuals).
- Balancing - there is some balancing to do.  It's not terrible, but some operators don't have really good weapons.  Shotguns need to be buffed just a little bit.
- Briefing screen - the game mode should stay in the briefing screen (where you select the operator and vote) because I choose operators according to the game mode and often times I miss that 1 second screen...disadvantages of having SSDs...
- Kicking rules - add a required field that asks why somebody is getting voted to kick...apparently I got kicked for being...too good? 41 kills...at least I could take a screenshot and show it to my friends for a good laugh.
- Mic?! - seems like half or more of the players that talk in game do not realize they are...lol make sure you put push to talk AND treshold to 0.  Not sure why push to talk by itself does not work.
- No host migration - ...come on...I don't like getting kicked to the main menu because the host died at the end and ragequits...
- No offline - cannot play without an internet connection.  You have to be connected to their servers even if you are playing solo (unless you are doing the situations, but no reward).
- Servers/matchmaking - while it is in the pros, it is also in the cons because they can definitely be worked on.

I know there is something I am forgetting.  I will add it as it comes to my mind.

SummaryThe game is good!  I won't say worth it or not since $60 is worth one thing to me and another to you, but you can find it for cheaper if you search well.  Personally speaking, YES, it is ABSOLUTELY worth it.
You can play PVE or PVP, whatever you like!  Good graphics, good gameplay, lots of fun!
Definitely a game to pick up, especially if you like FPS and coops games.  Just be aware that it is slower than most shooters.  I wouldn't say it's tactical, but it's not a run and shoot.  You should give it a shot.  If you can play it with friends, it's even better! (even though I seem to play worse with them because I get distracted lel)

Let me know what you think. :)

reviewText:
This game I have to say imo blows most other competive mp shooters away.

Its been a while since my heart has raced during a shooter. The immersion is insane.
Graphics are decent nothing mind blowing.

Once you see what can be done, your hunger to experiment snags you.

The game is also fairly intuitive and everything begins to make sense very quickly. However the ability to execute what is learned takes skill.

Not really sure what network issues people were complaining about, I haven't encountered any. Nor any bugs except for one random crash.

More Thoughts

Uplay is really the only downside, however for most of my time during the game it was quickly forgotten.
There is no story...
The price of this game should go down to maybe 40 or 30.
The community so far seems nice however when the casual and more serious players mix the open mic can get obnoxious. Aka people ♥♥♥♥♥ing at others for sucking or not doing well.
The team play that I have experienced tends to be more on the non verbal side and people just stick together.
The class system is kinda nice, but sucks when the class you want is taken.

Theres more that can be said but if you like insurgency, cs go, and many more titles YOU WILL LIKE THIS.

reviewText:
I'm sad, but i just can't give this game a positive review. I have more than 100 hours in this game, unlocked every operator, every attachment, and i own the season pass aswell. I really enjoy this game... WHEN and IF it works. What does that mean?

Almost three months after the launch, the servers are still ♥♥♥♥. Pings start around at 70, and the player with the bigger latency got the peeker's advantage. Which means he can kill you before you even see him.  Cool huh?

Hitreg is also broken most of the time. Even if you shoot the enemy, and he clearly bleeds ( like this[imgur.com]), it happens that you deal minimal, or no damage at all, even with a headshot.

Also, you have a shield? Sometimes it doesn't matter, because you can get shot through the shield, even if you face the enemy (even while crouching).

Recent event (at least for me): Couldn't get through a PERFECTLY OPEN door, cause the moment i walked in, some rubberband tossed me out instatly. Same with the grenades, i threw them in, and they flew out...

And the list goes on and on. Cheaters on higher ranked levels (plat and above), though every game got these scum, it looks like fairfight is not doing it's job properly. Good news that in casual there are hardly any cheater. Hurray!

Otherwise, the game itself is fantastic. Very intense with interesting strategy opportunities, requires a good teamplay. Got a really good graphics, the level desing is cool, the sounds are great (they can also be funny"

reviewText: OVERVIEWRainbow Six: Siege is the newest title in the long-running Tom Clancy Series. It focuses on intense, competitive multiplayer matches pitting attacking and defending teams against eachother in a battle of brains and skill. For newcomers, Seige is very similar to games like Counter-Strike with 5v5 round based gameplay. What make's it different from those games is a combination of highly destructible enviroments, unique gadgets and abilities for certain characters and a variety of options to attack and defend the objective such as rappeling from windows and roofs and using the environment against your enemies. For Veterans to the series the game is very different from the usual Single-Player Focused campaign where you can work with bots who obey your commands or real teammates who work with you to tactically clear buildings, save hostages and eliminate threats. Thankfully there is a Terrorist Hunt" mode that offers you the option of doing just that. It's not entirely the same
date: but it's something at least. This particular game's main focus is the Multiplayer and i'm perfectly okay with that

reviewText: Like CS:GO but not ♥♥♥♥
voteText: 93 of 149 people (62%) found this review helpful 58 people found this review funny

reviewText:
This is a case of wasted potential.
Alright,

I don't like putting up negative reviews, since most of the time it just comes down to personal preference when I don't like a game, but this is just hilarious.

First off:
The game itself is not bad at all. In fact, i really enjoy playing it. The concept and gameplay elements are great and me and my friends already had a lot of fun playing this.

But I just can't deal with the bad things going on this game...

For starters:
The matchmaking is just plain bad, in casual and rankeds alike.
It's probably the worst I've ever seen since CS:GO Competitives.

It's neither fun nor helping me improving my game always having to play against people who have hundreds of hours more gametime than me. And while I may be able to overlook this in casuals, the Rankeds are almost impossible to win with the kind of players the matchmaking comes up with.

Best example: Me and a friend, both on like Silver 3, had to play against a group with one Gold guy and even two Platinum guys, which was probably because the other two silverguys in the enemyteam got boosted by these guys.
So, my question is: Why is that even possible? Even CS:GO prevents boosting of that magnitude.
And in every other ranked we played we always got matched against people who were of higher rank than us. Not even one time were they lower than us.
Also, the matchmaking in rankeds takes really long. I would understand that if it would match us with people of the same skilllevel. But thats not what it does, so why does it even take so long?

Second:
There is a kind of gamebreaking bug, where after you pick your operator and the time runs out, there comes a short loading screen, and then you get into the game. The bug simply wont let the loading finish and you are mostly stuck there forever. I think there was like one time where it finished loading after like 5 minutes, but in all other cases it wouldnt start even after 30 minutes.
So, this is a AAA-Game published by a pretty big company.
This bug existed since the beta, and they still havent been able to fix that?
So i basically paid money for not being able to play the damn game, because every 2 or 3 games that bug happens.

Maybe it's just my bad luck, but that doesnt change the fact that it exists for months, and I haven't found any statement as to why this happens and if they are actually concerned about that or no.


Third: The anti-cheat system (aka FairFight)

As far as I know, it consists of analyzing your keystrokes while playing to see, if you push any button which is not binded in the controls, a fair number of times for like hackmenus etc.
And of course checking KDA with skilllevel, blablabla.
So, bascially its a math-based algorithm.
What happens when you have a math-based algorithm and the possibility to report people ingame after you get owned by a player?
Yes: You get banned wether you actually cheated or not.
Which is actually what happened to a friend of mine after getting a few good flickshots on his enemies.
So he got suspended from the game for a few minutes, even though he just played normally.
Twice.

Great stuff. Not like we don't have any experiences of bad completely automatic anti-cheatsystems.
It usually results in more work for the support.... oooh.... wait.
The support doesn't care. At least thats what I could see by seeing multiple threads regarding anti-cheat and other topics (like that little bug) where the people basically got no answer even after weeks of waiting.

Well.... BEST ANTI-CHEAT SYSTEM EVER!


Still, that's not the worst problem since I'm not affected, because I'm bad at shooter anyway.

Anyway.


Forth:
The netcode.
On console this might even work in favor of the players as they are playing with controllers so some delay will work in their favor as they need longer to aim at their target.
But we are playing this on a computer, we don't have that problem. But Ubisoft didn't account for that, just made a simple port, and now it just feels like another Call of Duty.


The last, but least important thing:

The community.

Judging from all those reviews on Steam, the community is THE BEST OF EVERY GAME IN EXISTENCE.
Okay, maybe thats overestimating it, but still, there are alot of those reviews.

Comparing it to like CS:GO, yes the community is by far better, but on the other hand, CS:GOs community is one of the worst things I've seen anyway...
Any yes, mostly the people who actually did talk, were nice and easy to talk to.

But still, there were more than enough people I played with or against who though they were the best in the world, and being arrogant and all that stuff, which was kinda annoying, so I don't really get why people would go all over the good" community like that

Also: Casuals + Community

If Ubisoft get rid of most cheaters, I will remake this review.
R.I.P.

reviewText:
UPDATED REVIEW (Andjusted Review for BLACK ICE UPDATE!)

I've put many more hours and was finally able to play ranked matches since my last uninformed review. So here's my stance on the game right now: ♥♥♥♥ing Fantastic, for the most part anyway.

This game has everything it needs to grow a reliable and consistent playerbase. Rainbow Six Siege's asymmetric style of gameplay is unique, and it seems very fresh. This arena shooter pits two teams of 5 operators against each other in intense extremely close quarters combat. The environment could be either your biggest ally or your worst enemy, depending on which team you're on or how your team's been handling a situation. While I think this game is great I cannot argue that it has some issues. Here are simple pros and cons to wet your appetite for destruction.

PROS:

- Fantastic destruction based gameplay forces you to think and adapt to any situation.

- Has serious competitive potential. Ranked mode is good, but obviously the people playing for keeps aren't so nice. Ever.

- SO MANY OPERATORS!

CONS:

- Microphone communication is a must. Text chat is limited to less than 6 words, making communication difficult for those who are either afraid to talk to people, or don't have a microphone. Sometimes, people don't even talk. At all. This makes the game unwinnable a lot. (EDIT: UBISOFT HAS EXPANDED THE AMOUNT OF LETTERS IN TEXT CHAT SIGNIFICANTLY, DISREGARD)

- The community is very hit or miss at best. One can play 10-12 games and only 2 out of those 10-12 would be good, fair, non ♥♥♥♥♥y teammates who take responsibility for their shortcomings instead of blaming the rest of the team. Blaming the rest of the team is only okay if the rest of the team is actually to blame, which is often not the case.

- Matchmaking seems to enjoy hooking people up globally. Which means that damn language barrier strikes again.

- Terrorist hunt. My darling Terrorist hunt what have they done to you... Classic Terrorist Hunt mode is a rarity at best when Ubisoft decided it would be a good idea to just shoehorn in other game modes. And they're terrible.

Overall, Rainbow Six Siege is a great team based game if you have a mic, patience, and good sportsmanship. So grab a corner, make yourself comfortable, and pray to god the enemy team doesn't have Thermite.

7/10

P.S.: The reviews angelizing the community are incredibly situational and subjective. Those reviewers got lucky and got matched up with great players. I never do. Don't buy the game based on the community because you will be thoroughly disappointed.

BLACK ICE UPDATE: Oh Ubisoft. You make me so happy but also so, so mad. Black Ice is the first official content update of R6 Siege and it looks promising. It adds a new map and two new operators. It was released on Feb 2nd, but I can't access the content until the 8th... what the hell Ubisoft. They are pushing this season pass HARD.

I considered lowering the score and giving the game a thumbs down but hell. Every AAA company pushes their season passes so who cares. I can wait a tad longer. I am glad that I get access to the balance update at least. And boy what a hefty balance update it is. Also I found it hilarious to see that Ubisoft still has a sense of humor.

Thatcher finally got his shotgun. Thanks, Ubi.

reviewText: This game is awesome, REALLY awesome but recently, there has been a lot of problems with the comunity, a lot of people on this review page say the comunity is nice and cool, but here's the thing, its changing. For one thing, the amount of TeamKillers has increased dramatically, especially if you play on casual, One time I went into a match on Bank, on offensive and was imediatly killed by a guy, I waited for someone to kill him cause well he was an as@hole, but nobody did, and I realized they didn't because they were playing together, like they knew eachother, and aparrently they wanted to play alone, people like this ruin the game, and ubisoft needs to do something to properly punish players that do this. Also I have recently been encountering nice and friendly people less and less, just more as@holes. There are three kinds of people I play with in this game, mostly guys who dont have mics, don't coordinate and don't comunicate with their team and get themselves killed first, secondly there are asses who will coordinate with you, but insult and criticize you for every mistake you make, (you'll encounter these guys mainly on ranked they don't like inexperienced players) and lastly the friendly people, who are rare now. They will help you give the needed call outs and back you up in a match and those are the best people in this game. And even with everything I said, its still not enough to not recomend this game, just if you are gonna buy it, try to find a clan or just some friends to play it with if you can, cause the randomes are wild cards now, thank you for taking the time to read this review and I hoped it helped you make your decision because this is one of the most tactical and team based multiplayer fps's of this decade and its an amazing accomplishment by Ubisoft. reviewText:
'Tom Clancy's Rainbow Six Siege is a first-person shooter video game developed by Ubisoft Montreal and published by Ubisoft.'
Ubisoft have taken back the initiative with their innovative FPS, Rainbow Six: Siege.

What it lacks in the single player department, it by far makes up for in multiplayer. One will spend numerous hours, and more, addicted to high octane game mechanics.

Rainbow Six: Siege brings to the table new concepts: breaching, scaling buildings, drones and special abilities, are the primary four. Core to the game, they sum up to a great pandemonium that never ages.

'Operators' – the twenty-four characters you can play as – each count to the game, and each have a special ability. These abilities range from sniper scopes to EMP grenades; all of which contribute to matches, and none of which overpower the others.

Contrary to other shooters, Rainbow Six: Siege does not allows you to pick up weapons; rather, you are stuck with starting primary and secondary weapons, gadgets and grenades. Therefore, each operator has a unique style and mode of game-play.

Matches consist of rounds of offense and defence, and there are three modes: bomb, hostage and secure area. In a bomb game, you either defend the bombs, or you try to disarm them; the alternative is to slay the enemy team.

There are 12 maps, small, medium or large sized, and no map is boring to play. You may scale the sides of buildings if you're on offense; breach through floors, walls, windows or doors with charges, guns or explosives; and if you're on defence, you can fortify walls or floors so that they cannot be breached by normal means.

You may customize operators to an extent, with more options coming in 'Dust Line update'. You have a collection of skins for weapons that you can buy, earn or some combination of both – in 'Dust Line', the rumour is that you can change head gear. Custom games are simple to create; there aren't much settings you can change, so there is minimal customization.

The sound in Rainbow Six: Siege is incredible and precise; you'll use your ears more than your eyes, and pick up more kills through sound than sight. A headset is necessary to get the most out of multiplayer.

The graphics of Rainbow Six: Siege are streamlined. With a HD texture pack that you can download to tweak  the graphics to perfection, they will always catch your attention. Explosions, bullets and the physics are all realistic, as well as the characters.

Terrorist Hunt and Situations are modes that can be played on your own. Terrorist Hunt is player(s) versus bots, with three difficulties and various scenarios; and Situations is player versus bots, generally used for start-out experience.

You earn renown each game you play, and it can be spent on weapon upgrades, skins and in the 'Dust Line update', more. You may buy R6 credits to bypass some needs of renown gain.

Positive'Adrenaline rushy' multiplayer.
Fast-paced and technical gameplay.
Original and unique mechanics.
Realistic graphics.
Precision sound.
Fun operators and cool abilities.
Tactical opportunities.
ESL affiliated.
Maps packed with content.NegativeCheaters in matchmaking.
Some hit detection problems.
“Overall K/D” and not “Recent K/D” ratio.Overall10/10

If you liked this review or want to see more recommended games, be sure to follow our curator group:  Follow Original Curator Group

reviewText:
So after about 200 hours in the game I can write a negative review without hesitation. If you like:
-horrible netcode(frequent headshots up to 1,5m off the target), which won't ever be fixed,
-cheaters every higher ranked game, who will never be banned,
-million bugs and glitches,
-high ping,
-many matchmaking problems,
-weapon skins bought for the real currency even if you have a game and season pass for ~80€ together,
then this game is for you.

Advantages:
-huge esport potential which is wasted because of issues mentioned above

Don't buy unless u want to get irritated most of the time or will buy a cheat.
And now more serious statement: I'd say buy only if you don't care about ranked games, play just for fun, you'll enjoy unique action this game provides, especially when playing with friends.

reviewText:
You CANNOT justify that this game is worth £49.99. It's a decent game don't get me wrong, it's just really not worth the money.

EDIT: In the essence of it all it's my opinion. Someone else may love this game and think it's worth every penny. As I have stated, the game is good and I do like it, my only gripe is the value for money. The AI isn't the best during single player segments and I hate how you can't pick your map/side (attack or defence) when creating either a private or single player game.

All in all it's the little things, however I stand by my previous statement that it isn't worth the price. You have other AAA games like Fallout 4 and Just Cause 3 priced at £39.99 and there is no justification for the extra £10.00 in Siege's case.

EDIT 2: Yes, I know that they have dropped the price to £39.99 now but my opinion still stands. It is good of them to realise that they were overcharging but it shouldn't be like that in the first place. If the game goes on sale and further reductions apply then it will definitely be worth the money as it is a brilliant game.

reviewText:
This game is... lets face it... dreadful.

I had so much hope and such good hopes for the game and to have them completely ruined.
This game cost me around £60, which for what I tried in both the Alpha and Beta stages seemed like a fair price for an amazing gameplay opportunity.
I'll be completely honest, the gameplay on this game is fantastic, sure the hitregistration and the netcode should be way way better for what is to be considered a competetive FPS but I do really enjoy running around gunning people down and generally having a great laugh with my friends, but the other half of the game is just ridiculous.

Pros:
-Gameplay is amazing.
-The Concept of the game with both attack and defence rounds is awesome and seeing peoples ideas and strategies unfold really nice.
-Being able to play with friends as a team works really nicely.

Cons:
-The Networking on the game is horrific, taking over 10 tries to actually get in a lobby that actually works and doesn't bug.
-Getting into an ACTUAL game is harder than trying to breach Fort Knox.
-The lobbying system apparently doesn't want me to have friends because it is FOREVER disbanding my squad/team for NO reason.
-The hit-reg between players is really bad, I have had many of times that I have quite blatantly shot a person in the face repeatedly for them to return fire, kill me and my headshots have done about 10% damage to their health.
-The PlayerModels and the reg between player models, Ash's player model does not match her HitBoxes and therefore she can sprint around dodging bullets like Neo on a Sunday Afternoon whilst breaching your ♥♥♥♥ and 5 man killing your team, where as the other Operators don't seem to have the same issues.

All in all, the game has great gameplay but it takes approximately 30-40 minutes in order to actually find a server/game that is worth playing and by that point there's still approximately 40-50% chance of somebody having connection issues and DCing from either team sometimes even everybody. - To the point that the game is hardly even worth playing, you spend more time trying to get in a game and ending up being frustrated and annoyed than actually playing the game.

If I were to rate the game on a scale of 0-10... it'd get probably a 2/10. - as said, the gameplay is amazing but due to all of the ridiculous issues with this game it is pretty much completely ruined.

The game still feels like it is in Beta, never mind a full release valued at £40+

Not only is AI almost brain dead, but once you get to the hostage, it spawns additional enemies, so the way to play the hostage missions is to get to the hostage, take him with you, immediately drop, clear out the spawned reinforcements, take the hostage and move to the exit location.

And then you repeat this 11 times in a row, because these missions" give you a lot of renown

reviewText:
Although Tom Clancy's Rainbow Six isn't like the original tatical shooters still requires a degree of tatics and communication with teams  with the core concept of the game revolving around a five man team of Attackers (cops)  to infiltrate against the Defenders(terrorist) in Disarming a biochemical explosion or saving a hostage. Each team switches out at the end of the round and the best out of six wins the game.
Players can shoot through certain materials, create holes in walls, rappel buildings, and use gadjets to accomplish this task.

You might wonder why this game is worth the price as an online only multiplayer gameplay. If you think about it the game has ten operators (Classes) on each team. Each is unique to itself and the fact that you'll be playing possibly one of the operators unless someone picks it.  The combinations of operators changes up the gameplay with thier unique gadjets. The players you play with will be diffierent everytime with thier strength and weakness. There are 10 decently sized map with multiple floors or buildings. You have randomized spawnings for both sides (Until ranked).  Every scenario and experience is completely different.
They come from above
They can come from the side
They come from the sewers
they busted the windows
It all comes down to the gameplay and the different scenarios everytime and that is what keeps it fresh and fun for days.

Pros + Communication and teamwork for success (Players actually work with each other)
+ Great amount of work put into balance between the operators (Classes)
+ The 10 maps are all nicely made and the fact that the bomb/hostage can end up anywhere depending on team adds variation to the scenario everytime
+ The sound effects are very nice
+ The graphics and effects from blowing up walls, breaching, light shaking when breaches are made and bodies hanging from rappels.
+ The concept behind players death you can still help the team by taking over cameras and communicating with your teamates instead of fiddling your thumbs until the next match.
+ It differs itself from the large amount of fps you have on the market today. Much more fresh than your typical run and gun. Try being one of those guys and you'll see.


Cons - Tickrate at 16-32 for servers. ( How fast server gets information between your client) Hopefully they fix this. Sometimes you'll notice it if you are a competitive fps player or in general understands how this works.
- People hate microtransaction, but it isn't too bad in this game due to the fact that it only deals in boosting how much points you earn or skins.
- server issues even though its on dedicated server but might be due to launch issues.
- Lack of variety of game modes since the core concept is revolved around attackers vs defense. It does offer single player but serves more of a training. There is also a Player vs Terrorist mode (Pve) with others.
- No single player campaign and online only, not even a offline gameplay of any sort. Some of you might be turned off because of this but it is a heavily focused online game.
- Not as much customization in terms of weapons and each classes is limited to around 2-3 guns but they all use different weapons for each class.

reviewText:
Looking for a game that's competitive and doesn't have many bugs? Well this isn't the game for you.

Firstly, the game's servers currently run on 15 tick. For people who know what it is that's enough to know its horrible. If you dont know, 15 tick means the server reads and sends out data for player movement, shots and other actions 15 times a second. The minimum for games that want to be competitive is 64, and for high skill competitive tournaments it is usually 128.

Secondly, the game is plauged with bugs, body parts can clip through walls, your body is not correctly shown (you can see your legs are not in front of you, but to other people they are), The in-game sound can stop completely until the next round starts, you can get stuck in objects, and drones often fall through the map.

Thirdly, and this may be because of the 15 tick servers, but movement and combat feels extrememly floaty and CODlike, the hitboxes are terrible, and often you are being killed when you are already around a corner. The guns all feel like they are just the same gun with different skins.

I've alerady requested a refund, if they fix most of the bugs and the terrible 15 tick servers, I may rebuy. But if you were interested in this as a competitive game, don't buy it.

Edit: While the 15 tick rate is unconfirmed it is very obvious from playing the game it is not high enough and the claims it was 15 were believable for me, as in-game you hear 1 shot but in the kill cam's damage log it shows as 5. And as for refunds they are done on a case per case basis so there is not a 0% chance I won't get my money back.

reviewText:
RB6 Siege is a fast paced mix of tactical, team-based shooting.  The game is a solid effort comparable to it's peers.  If you enjoy Insurgency or CS:GO it's probably a no-brainer to pick up at some point.

Aside from the relatively enjoyable gameplay, I don't care for the console-friendly aspects of matchmaking (no server browser or custom servers, only Ubisoft's Opaque and clunky matchmaking service).  And the UI is not optimized for kb/m.  These issues are unfortunatley commonplace to virtually all cross-platform titles so not unexpected.

Despite the solid gameplay however, I do regret my purchase.  For the AAA price tag, the content is simply not there.  Add in Ubisofts aggressive and persistent microtransaction system and I'm left feeling dirty -- like I've just been taken for a ride.  At the $60 price point, Ubisoft is bordering on exploitation with the current offering.

Bottom line:  Solid game but Developer's level of greed is excessive and feels insulting.  Wait a few months for the inevitable sales or discounted DLC content.

reviewText:
First time I've written a review for a game on steam so here goes nothing. A lot of the complaints from people who have bought the game or are considering buying the game originate from the fact that the game has limited content. After playing the game for almost 50 hours now and seeing the plans for future dlc I think that this criticism is legitimate.

Content:

The game has 20 operators able to be unlocked. By doing the 10 prologue missions and completing all the per-mission challenges you are able to unlock about 10 of these operators so within the first 10 hours or so of gameplay you have already unlocked half of the game's content. I'm not sure why ubisoft would make this possible as for a game that will not have paid dlc and is supposed to be a grind for in game content they've made it waaay to easy to quickly unlock everything within a very short time frame. It is for this reason that the game begins to feel stale after unlocking most of the operators.

Balancing problems:

The next problem with siege's operators are that they aren't balanced very well. This is a very large issue because this game is intended to be an esport in the near future. If they want to compare themselves to games like league of legends, they have to do a better job of making each of the operators relevant. Anyone who has played the game for a little while will quickly realize that the best attackers are by far thermite and fuse, while the best defenders are arguably rook, and mute. These operators will be quickly taken by your teammates leaving inferior operators for you to take. Yes the others can be useful in certain situations but thats it, certain situations, instead of basically any situation for the OP ones.

Ranked:
I was pretty excited to hit level 20 so that I could start playing competetively. Unfortunately even in ranked many people elect to not use a mic, which greatly limits the amount of coordination that you can have. This fact basically ruins the ranked system for me, since the whole point of this game is teamplay and communication. Maybe they will introduce a better system of communication for those without mics (like the pinging system in LOL, but until then its a pretty big issue. There are also issues with matchmaking which make finding a game take forever, but hopefully this will be fixed eventually. These issues will not help in building a bigger community for the game in the future.

DLC plans:
For a game that allows you to unlock half of the ingame content through doing the prologue missions, the fact that they are planning on bringing out only 8 operators in the next year greatly concerns me. When you compare this game to LOL, another competitive teambased game, LOL began with about 17 different characters. Over the next year after its release, they brought out another 25 characters. Thats more than a 100% increase in in-game content, and was one of the main reasons why LOL is the most played game in the world now. Of course its not a great comparison because theyre two different games, but it should give people an understanding of the expected longetivity of this game.

TLDR: Yes the game has limited content, which is unlocked all-to-quckly. Balancing problems make many of the game's characters feel unuseful. Ranked gameplay is underwhelming currently. And the future DLC plan will not be enough to keep the game's community growing.

Verdict: I see a lot of people doing buy, wait for sale or don't buy in their reviews. My verdict is to wait for a sale. The game has a number of issues, which aren't helped by the game's release price. Getting this game at a better price will make the game's issues less annoying, and since all future dlc is free there's no reason to rush into getting the game. Wait and see if the game is dead in a few months before buying.

reviewText:
This is rainbow six evolved
I've played every rainbow six game. Especially rainbow six vegas 1 and 2. And let me tell you... They did exactly what needed to be done to expand this franchise in the right direction.

What is this game all about?
It is about tactical close quarter combat. May it be fast paced or slow paced. All up to you and your team. It is a 5v5 setup with the teams taking turns attacking and defending. The defenders prepare defenses and traps while the attackers send in small drones to locate either a bomb, hostage or biohazard inside the building. And simply gather information about the defensive setup.

After this first stage of the battle the attackers try to break through the defenses and complete the objective however they see fit. The defenders hold them back until the time runs out or the attackers are dead.

This is the core game summed up.

Why is this game good? What is has been done right?
Walls!
Most walls inside the buildings can be destroyed one way or another. Many walls can be sprayed with bullets and leave bullet sized holes to peek through. Many roofs and floors can be shot through or breached through. You have to be super aware to be prepared. To be prepared from attackers raining fire from below, above, sides, front and back.
No room is safe.

Operators!
The game has several different types of operators. The attackers and defenders each have a set of them to choose from.  They either give you and your team a tactical advantage or are just better at killing and absorbing bullets in different ways. It is up to you and your team to decide what will work best. What combinations of operators will give you the best advantage.

A slight misstep can cost you your life while it still being fair.
Having people to play and communicate with gives you a massive tactical advantage. There's so much variation to what you can do.
The tension of hearing the attackers moving around the room you're defending, hearing ropes outside the windows, hearing charges being put on walls around you. Those few seconds before everything goes wild… magical!

I once killed three enemies while being the last one alive and the enemy team congratulated me. (WHAT?!)
I once accidentally shot a teammate in the head and he didn't yell at me. Instead he forgave me and kept on supporting me and the rest of my team.. (DOUBLE WHAT?!)
I've yet to run into any salty or grumpy players. Which is hard to say about most games.

Cheaters? I’ve yet to run into a cheater of any kind. I think the people complaining about cheaters just don't know how to be aware of their surroundings.

The game looks amazing. Explosions are not overdone and looks perfect. The sound engineers of this game did a marvelous job.

What's is missing? What could have been done better?
No proper storyline or campaign!
The rainbow six games have had decent stories with some pretty fun co-op gameplay. This is missing completely and i understand why paying a full price and not getting any of that is a disappointment. Many are. As am i! The mechanics and destruction would have made quite the intense story missions.
The menus are not well done at all. No thought given to custom game modes... and choosing what map you and your buddy want to play on is fiddly and confusing.

While the current maps are good and fun to play on… I can see them getting old after a while. I hope they plan to make new ones.

Summary

The game is fun, hard, tense, challenging, not to hard to learn… Though it is hard to be good at.

Better co-op gameplay would have been nice… While terrorist hunt is fun and is always welcome to any rainbow six game… It still doesn’t compare to what could have been done.

reviewText: This game is hands down one of the most innovative games the FPS genre has seen in a decade.  You and your team must plan and execute unique strategies in multiple different game modes ranging from Hostage Rescue, to Terrorist Hunt.  Although there isn't much of a single player, the tutorial missions play out in an oddly satisfying, campaign-like scenario!  Perhaps the most interesting aspect of this game is the fact that all the operators are based are real-world counter terrorist units.  My only criticism would be the inconsistent networking issues which sometimes makes playing with your friends a tad difficult.  That being said, when it works, it's amazing!  Do yourself a favor and pick up this incredible shooter!

reviewText:
Do not buy/support this game.
This game is fun and the concept is cool, but here's the issue:
If you've played Battlefield 4 in early beta, you know how ridiculous the netcode was. Rainbow Six Siege is like that, but worse. Your client registers 8 bullets as ONE impact and you instantly die. Getting killed eventhough you ran behind cover. Bullets not going where they should. Getting killed by someone and seeing on replay that he didn't even aim at you. Your body goes through walls while taking cover so the enemy can kill you from behind a wall. Hell, I even insta-killed a guy with a headshot while shooting him ONCE in the stomach, yup that's right.... in the stomach.
I tried getting my money back, because paying 60 euros for a broken game is not something I want to support, but alas; steam support and refund policy won't cover it.
60 Euros for this game at this stage, is WAY overpriced and people should not support it.

reviewText:
Core gameplay is great but the bugs and community bring the game down to the point its not worth even picking up on discount.
For starters the games completely multiplayer the only single player aspects are basically tuorials.

Every other match you play youre going to have to deal with either toxic players, laggy players, generally dodgy netcode or one of the great and many bugs that are completely game breaking.

For the toxic players you have your TKers, people who kill the hostage in that game mode, people who scream on the mic which the game doesnt seem to limit the volume of and just generally abusive toxic players.

More often than not theres at least one person in the game with a ping over 150 and regularly in the 200-250ms range and at those stages they will be teleporting and shooting you around corners or you will think youre hitting them but you only hit air... you know same ol' crappy netcode and bad matchmaking.

Speaking of the matchmaking, its horrible, it takes forever and frequently has fits where it locks up and can never seem to find a group of players all in your geographic area.

The bugs are rediculous. You have people getting stuck in loading screens, entire lobbies of players getting caught in load screens, players joining games but seeing nothing but the load screen for the first match, players joining and the game not loading 90% of the graphics and more.

Aside from those things and probably a handful or so other minor issues the game itself its great and a lot of fun but be honest with yourself, if you dont already own this than youre better off not joining a sinking ship because the community and the bugs arent goingn anywhere.

reviewText:
During the ALPHA and BETA phases I couldn't be less interested in this game. However after seeing some gameplay footage and instruction videos I decided to give it a shot. In short I can describe this game as a FPS chess game. Yes chess. :) By that I mean you wont ever have two exaclty the same eras in this game. There are so much factors that each round feels (and actually is) different. Don't fool yourself by thinking this is another Call of Duty / Counter Strike copy. It isn't.

+ Etremely fun to play as soon as you learn how to play it properly
+ Very slow pace
+ Rewards teamplay
+ Good variety of maps
+ Winning makes you cheer
+ The more you play it the better it gets

- Pretty heavy on hardware compared on it's looks (4790K @ 4,7GHz, GTX 980 Ti)
- Matchmaking system

reviewText:
This game is really damn good.
Siege provides room for usage of tactics and clever positioning, where map knowledge is key, as well as moments of pure visceral action once all hell goes loose during a breach.
The core gameplay is extremely enjoyable. I've sunk 130hrs into in at the moment of writing this review (Game bought on Dec. 15), and I plan on playing a lot more of it.
DLC content is all free for everybody, with season pass owners skipping a (rather easy) grind for Renown to unlock DLC operators. The only stuff that is not available for in-game currency is some of the camo patterns for your guns, which hold absolutely no value apart from cosmetical.

That said, at this moment (Jan 29 2016) the game is still plagued by a variety of server, hitreg and netcode issues, hackers in Ranked mode, and lacking UI. The game is enjoyable at the moment, but it's definitely not bug-free. I shall update this reviews once the issues have been fixed.

A cautious recommendation for an excellent game plagued by network problems.
