reviewText:
Review time....And this one is difficult for me, on the one hand there is a unique and beautiful masterpiece of a game hidden under its many flaws, but then again the fact that I say many flaws is contradictory to the matter at hand of a complete and sound experience.
So here is my overall opinion on the matter, the game truly shines in team play with friends, and I do really enjoy playing a objective based game again versus some run and gun like a COD, so thats while not necessarily a new thing but none the less its refreshing. Secondly the game has some cool and unique things to put it apart from other games such as counterstrike, with addtions in it such as repelling, using explosive charges to destroy walls/open up new routes on the map, infact the destructibility in the game should be very much noted. I do also enjoy the champion/hero style of play where you pick a character with unique skill sets and weapons to play as and the mix of them on your team can make or break a game like a match of say league or dota, so that aspect is cool and yet again while its not a new concept I like seeing it implimented in a tactical fps shooter.


Alright so here are my gripes, first and foremost the game suffers quite a bit from more than questionable deaths you will no doubt run into while playing because of server latinence, secondly there is some problems partying up with friends and dropping in out of matches randomly losing all your progress and Xp which can be very frusturating. Thirdly there are most certainly some balancing issues with the title as well be it with some characters have weapons that seemingly one shot you or abilities that are a bit over powered and abused game after game, one that will stand out more than any other which was a problem in the beta and is still a problem in the full release is the characters whom wield shieds, with pistols being a 1-5 shot kill depending on where you hit the enemy and what pistol used it can be very annoying to dump your magazine in the shield players feet and or sides and they turn and pop you in a couple shots......
One more very particular annoyance in the game is you may be running a very respectable machine such as myself Amd Fx 8350, 32gb of ddr3 with a geforce gtx 780, a machine that can easily take on bf4, battlefront, titanfall, crisis 3 and other AAA titles on high or ultra settings and Rainboe Six is no exception....for the most part, you will find yourself playing several matches in a row and then your fps just for no real reason take a massive hit, the problem usually requires a game restart to fix, or if your lucky it will correct itself upon the start of the next match.


Final Thoughts:
Okay so this is one cool freaken game, that I will say first and foremost but then again it has some glaring faults that having played many fps titles over the years I found very annoying and down right childish to be in a big of a game release like this, so all in all its a cool game, cool concept, thats a bit too unpolished for me to reccomend in its current state, I would say maybe pick it up when it hits around 30-40 dollars on steam or grab it cheap on a key website or something but the 60 dollar asking price from Ubisoft is too steep at this current time.

reviewText:
This game severely lacks content. It's singleplayer aspect is just a bunch of training missions or a lone wolf against the AI which I'll discuss the AI in a moment. All the modes revolve around one concept, attackers vs defenders. There isn't much of a balance issue between the two teams. However, unless you pair up with a pre-made team you will rarely find a team that will cooperate/communicate let alone speak the same language. The whole gameplay revolves around cooperating and working with teamates. There's nothing more fustrating than the lack of teamwork in a teamwork based game. Period.

The most fun I have does not come from the competitive play, but from terrorist hunt against the AI. That's because it requires the least ammount of communication of all the gamemodes. The AI, however, is too robotic. It's not realistic or lifelike. The AI seem to be set on a particular path based on what you do. It takes the immersion out of it.

Along with that, the sound is horrendous. It has a 2d/3d sound. To clarify, you can ear all around you in 3d on your 2d plane, but if something is above you, you won't be able to tell if it's above or below or on the same level. That's pretty important for a tactical, quick paced FPS like this. I'm also not the only one to have this problem as I've asked several people ingame while I was spectating them through the deathcam. I've had no other issues with my 7.1 surround sound with other games like Battlefront, Fallout 4, etc.

A lot of people were saying that the game has bad netcode, which it does, but the matchmaking is so terrible that it pairs you up with people globally that it doesn't matter because everyone is lagging. It's near unplayable under certain conditions. The client does not match what the server is showing. You see this clearly from the deathcam's and from surveilance cameras.

The matchmaking is one of the worst features of this game. Teams will be imbalanced (I've played a 3v5 games many times) and individual skill doesn't matter paired up against any pre-made team. Ever. When you play a casual multiplayer match you have to put up with peer-to-peer hosting meaning 100+ ping for most matches. Along with that, there's no anti-cheat or anti-grief system in place. Last night 2-12-2015 I've had at least one hacker (seeing through walls and scoring headshots, YouTube it if you think I'm only hackusations") every 3 matches. As far as griefers go
date: there is no way to punish them. You just have to leave the match or shoot them back. But if you have to kill a griefing teamate at the start of the match
recommended: odds are you aren't going to win or enjoy your game in general.\n\nI have to give this game in its current condition a 5/10. It's a below average game. For the price it's not even worth a quick fix. If you truely have an interest in the game
hoursPlayed: wait until price drops

reviewText:
Most reviews have given this game pretty good reviews with the same cons for almost every review.
They keep pushing the fact that there isnt enough depth....... As someone with over 900hrs on CSGO and having played it since 1.6 I can say that depth is relevant. People play dust 2 all day long year in year out without becoming bored because
it is the human adversary that adds depth and continual change to approach every round.

This game has a multitude of option on operators that arent merely skins but offer different ways to achieve victory that
suit your approach. EG wanna bust through the front door then take a meat shield and let your team walk in behind you. There are so many options on entry poitns that every match is significantly different.

This is a great game that deserves your attention if you enjoy team fps games that require a little bit of planning each round. The graphics are not mind blowing but serve to allow a large diversity of gamers access which is only going to give the game a longer shelf life. The sound is amazing with headphones and using sounds are paramount to victory.

It took a little bit of fiddling to get the game running the way i like in terms of FPS and look etc but otherwise the servers have been great and as an Aussie im getting 35ms and yet to have trouble getting a game under 20 secs.

I hope this helps you to make a decision but at the very worst you can get a refund using steam support if you dont like it. Cheers.

reviewText:
What can I say, played the beta and day one of the beta was abysmal match making issues, connection issues, and weird rubber banding as well as shots not registering.

I was done I was not going to buy this game. Came back last day of the beta and played for 2 hours straight. Some of the most tense, tactical game play I have ever had.

The unique specialists add a layer of strategy to the game that few other shooters have. the 5 on 5 mechanic is what I like I don't need 40 player massive battles. What I want is depth.

If you want a game that you have to work as a team with, that makes you question how to attack an objective and how to defend this game is more about responding to a changing environment and executing a carefully thought out plan.

If you play this like COD or BF4 you will not succeed.

As for the steam issue people have been having I was able to launch the game no issues and it works flawless.

I have no match making issues, no dropped games, and so far no rubber banding. This review may change but so far there is nothing like this game on the market.

reviewText:
300+ hours into the game. I should have stopped 200 ago.

This game is so fun, yet is one of the most unfair, unbalanced, and horribly scrapped together games i've sunk so much time into in a long while. Easy to learn, hard to master, but can so very quickly be ruined by the hacking, terrible matchmaking, and poor server quality.

TL:DR

If you're thinking of buying this game. Don't. There is no matchmaking to speak of. You'll be placed with opponents that will be level 100+ while you are level 1. There is no single player. Unless you want to be dying over and over and over again to higher level players, stray away from this game.

+Fun and interesting concept
+Great character and map design

-Poor quality servers
-Hackers/hackusation galore
-The worst damage model ever
-Shoddy hitboxes
-Obvious money grab

First off the good sides of the game. Rainbow Six Siege is hands-down one of the most entertaining and exciting games I have ever played. The level design makes sure that as a defender, you generally have nowhere safe to hide without extra reinforcement with a few exceptions. Each operator has their own flavorful playstyle and personality and unique guns and gadgets for all. That's pretty much where the fun stops.

Now time to slop on all the bad stuff like gravy. Each gun, regardless of damage, is a one-shot headshot. The lowest damage in the game possible is a P90 equipped with a silencer, which when shot at a level 3 armor with Rook plating, takes around 20 bullets in the legs. However, one shot in the head with it, you're dead. This adds a lot of skill (or luck, or hacks) to the game. Although this is realistic" it's simply not balanced in a gameplay perspective. You could have a pistol headshot you from across the entire map (around the size of a commercial plane) and you'll be dead. Where's the realism now?

The hit-registration and the server lag is garbage. Some operators have headphones on
date: which adds some distinction between player models. However these headphones count as the head hitbox
recommended: and when combined with the statement above
hoursPlayed: is a recipe for disaster. One operator in particular
voteText: Blitz
helpfulPercent: has a large riot shield protecting his upper torso and head. Or so it's supposed to. His headphones essentially double his hitbox so even if your shield is right between you and your attacker
votesHelpful: there's a chance that one bullet will stray to the side and clip your headphones which somehow result in a headshot.\n\nOn top of this is the servers which can be summarized in a steamy pile of crap. The servers run at 60 ticks
votesTotal: which is much better than the 30 or even 15 it had launch and beta. But it's still not enough when all it takes is a single bullet from ANY gun to kill you. All of this
votesFunny: compounded by the effects of the Peeker's Advantage. For the uninformed it basically means when you round a corner you have a fraction of a second advantage over the stationary opponent because of the way servers refresh. So the absolute worst thing to happen in this situation is if Blitz is waiting around a corner
commentsCount: a dude runs right around the corner
column16: and gets a clip headshot on blitz through his headphones.\n\nAnd finally to sum it up we have the marketing for the game. It is so very obvious that this game is trying to be Counter Strike: Global Offensive. Everything they're trying to do screams CSGO. A tactical
column17: team based military shooter with two 5 man teams with one life that swap attacking and defending the objective. They put out more R6 Credit (their form of premium currency) skin bundles than they have patches to the game. Think about that. They held their pro league mere months after launch. This proves that above else Ubi is only in this for the money. They don't care about the game
column18: they have the Division (Mar 8th) which launched 4 months after Siege (Dec 1st).\n\nIn sum this game could be the breath of fresh air that the FPS genre needed. But it falls flat on its face so hard
column19: I predict that this game will essentially be dead before the end of the year."

reviewText:
This is a multiplayer, team-focused, strategic shooter, AAA title, 60$ game. In which you can't reach the multiplayer part 9 times on 10 because of the netcode and servers issues. But buying the Season's Pass apparently works just fine.
January 2016. Game has been released in early December 2015. Maybe in one month, it'll work. But there will be nobody left to play with.
Ubisoft, if that's the way you're going, I'm not following and I want a refund.

I can't recommend buying, at this price and in this state, Rainbow 6: Siege.

====================================================

Pros: the game is everything a strategic, slow-paced FPS aims to be. The game may needs some tuning and adjustement, but really minor stuff (often loudly requested by the community).

Mid: your teammates (and/or yourself) can be phenomenal mindplayers and teamworkers or all the way down to basic rushers and campers. This game requires you to cooperate and communicate, a concept that is sometimes forgotten. You'll have to improve yourself and do what you can with what you'll get.

Cons: the servers are in cardboard and the matchmaking is in plastic. For a game that offers maybe two hours of solo content, you can tell it's bad. This baby's only a few months old, and Ubisoft is apparently trying to kill it even before it matures. On the bright side, the server issues of Siege will make you feel better about any other's games server issues.

There are very serious issues with the way this game is put together.

A new player is forced to grind 15 - 30 hours (depends on your luck of win/loss) of casual" queue with probably the most hostile community I've ever dealt with. Casual queue features organized teams pub stomping your randomly thrown together team of racists and screaming children.

There is no balance to matchmaking in casual...rank 100+ and rank 1 are all together
date: it's possibly because of lack of players since matchmaking times can vary wildly between 5 minutes and HEAT DEATH OF THE UNIVERSE (Highest was 55 minutes on a saturday night). The matchmaking wait time is often longer than the match you eventually get into.\n\nThere's a good number of maps
recommended: and you better learn them fast because any mistake will get your teamates to kill you on your next spawn and rage at you for not having 200+ hours experience in "Casual" queue. You also can only mute voice
hoursPlayed:
not the chat. And you can't turn chat off.

You also start with none of the characters unlocked.
Unlocking all the different classes takes a long time
voteText:
even with boosters.
After 25 hours of play with a bonus xp weekend + a paid booster (a 100% XP boost total) I still have guys to unlock AND I'm only at rank 17...
You need rank 20 to get into ranked matches and out of Casual.

People have been reporting serious technical and compatibility issues such as crashing on launch
helpfulPercent: crashing randomly
votesHelpful: etc.\nThey've been reporting these issues since the game came out
votesTotal:
and there's no  fixes on the horizon.
The main technical issue I have is THERE IS NO ANTI CHEAT.
So the already toxic playerbase is also rife with hackers.

SPECULATION TIME:
It's worth noting the game is developed and produced by Ubisoft - who don't really do the 'games as a service' thing like Blizzard or Valve. So any serious changes or fixes that require significant dev time will probably be in a sequel rather than a patch.

TLDR: Competitive shooter with unmutable toxic players and no anticheat. Features tons of grinding and microtransactions."

reviewText: From an esthetic and innovative point of view, RSS is a nice game. The mechanics are fresh (breaching, surprising enemy,…) and the game will look good if your PC can follow.\nFrom a technical point of view, the game is a disaster: matchmaking errors, game breaking error (connection error which can make you leave a ranked match, and no system will allow you to come back in your match), bullet tickrate insanely bad, map bugs, animation bug, no report system, no ANTI-CHEAT system (we are a few month after release). Ubisoft quality of service and delivering a finished product IS NOT their priority.\nFor me this game is far from the AAA and price tag coming along that it claims. It is more like a “end-of-beta” game which need a lot of patches to be played in decent condition. If you are patient enough and don’t bother bugs (and lots of it). Then you will enjoy Siege. If not, I advise you to wait for the price to go down and the game to reach a “decent” playable state.

reviewText:
From June 2nd to June 19th, discover a new way to join the Rainbow Six Siege experience with the Starter Edition on PC.

PC players looking for an inexpensive way to jump into Rainbow Six Siege no longer have to wait until the next free weekend to get their fix. Starting June 2, a special Starter Edition of the game will be available for $15/€15 on PC for a period of two weeks. The Starter Edition offers the full Rainbow Six Siege experience, with all maps and Operators available, but unlocking new Operators works a little differently.

Those who buy the Starter Edition will immediately get access to two Operators, along with 600 R6 Credits to spend on two more Operators (or other unlocks) of their choice. The two initially available Operators are randomly chosen from a pool of six – Rook, Sledge, Ash, Fuze, Mute, and Smoke –determined to be the most intuitive for entry-level players. Additional operators can be unlocked in the Starter Edition by earning 12,500 renown (compared to 500-2,000 renown in the Standard Edition).

Aside from that difference, however, the Starter Edition includes access to the same maps, modes, level progression, weapon options, post-launch content, servers, and matchmaking options as the standard version, with zero restrictions and no level cap. The Starter Edition also works with the Season Pass, which grants immediate access to the eight post-launch Operators being added throughout 2016 (who are also available for 25,000 Renown or 600 R6 Credits each, which applies to both editions). Additionally, those who want to earn Operators a little more quickly can take advantage of the same Renown-boosting Daily and Weekly Challenges and weekly Operators discounts available to other players, and can purchase instant access to all 16 remaining Operators with a $35/€35 R6 Credits Bundle.

The Rainbow Six Siege Starter Edition will be available on PC through Steam and Uplay beginning June 2. Those who buy it will retain full access to the Starter Edition and all its content after the two-week sale period is over, letting you stay in the game as long as you want.

Thanks,
Great Game

reviewText:
This review is for how the game is as of 3/20/16.  I don't play Ranked, but I do play with a full team of friends.  I havnt bumped into any hackers, but not saying they are not there.

Siege gives a nice approach to teamwork based shooter with 5v5 teams with each sides having different operators that have different skills and limited loadout customizations.  Certain environments are destructable and can also be reinforced to prevent destruction or limit it.  Different types of objective based matches and multileveled maps.

Those are the pros.

Cons are what 'break' the game from me.  Such as:
However the way the game is coded, leaves certain players with advantages or disadvantages.
-Rubberbanding:  Can yank you around making infiltration impossible and even have C4 or grenades that you throw yank back to you and kill you.
-Being killed when no one is on my screen and turns out THEY WERE, but the game didnt update the movment of the enemy to me and therefore I didnt see them but I was on theirs.
-Similarly, while being shot at, running around the corner which is an indestructable wall and being HIT STILL BECAUSE THE GAME REGISTERS ME AS OUT IN THE OPEN.
-Or the enemy is just plain not on my screen when they are still, partially exposed, and full sights on me the entire time.
-Hit registration: Awful.  Empty half of my automatic assult rifle into an enemy that is crouched in front of me with his back turned, as I'm hitting him in his body and HEAD he casually turns around and kills me with his SMG in 2 shots.
-Matchmaking
-Inability to change loadouts or purchase items while in a lobby.
-Lack of proper info based on your teams loadout in the match lobby so the team can coordinate which items to use (think Payday 2)
-Another game where I suppose you cannot trust the Killcam to depict the other side of the story (it'll infuriate you)

Essentially, what happens on my screen is not actuality of what happens in the game, and for a FPS based on cover and environment I don't need that.  Maybe the developers will fix that, but probably not anytime soon.
I cannot see this game as being a serious competitive shooter.

reviewText:
Played this game for 60 hours during the 3 betas and have about another 40 hours in the release so far.  Nobody flipped out due to a one time accidental TK.  People actually work together in this instead of going 5 completely different directions.  The community so far has been positive and the game itself is solid.  Unlocked all operators and primary upgrades already and am working on gearing each operator up fully.  Can't wait for the new operator(s) and map(s) coming in Jan.  I bought the season pas since the game itself was a gift so a net spend of $30 was so worth it.  Get it on UPlay if you must to save money but this game is fun for those who are tired of the excessive repetition of other FPS run and shoot games.

Love the specialist operators and their abilities instead of one-dimensional characters in CS/COD/BF.  The destructible environments neverending ways to approach each map/mode are what keeps the game unique and fresh.  In CS everyone always went one of 2 or 3 ways and it became so predictable that after nearly 20 years of it, I wanted to play something different and this was just what I wanted.

Once netplay issues are resolved this game will be even better.  That and a mod community are all that is needed to make this game have more longevity like said FPS franchises above so we could have custom maps and scenarios.

Then you start noticing the HACKERS, in your and enemy teams. But don't worry, you kick him anyway and boom your connection just crash, I just wonder why. (ddos)

I paid 80$ cad for this game and I seriously regret it. Even if it was half the price I would have not buy it knowing all the issues above. The game is out of beta and it does not feel like a smooth experience. I bought this game because I expected it to be flawless at this price tag and it is years away from being flawless. I have allot more thing to say about this game but my review is already long enough like this and my engrish might give people cancer already.

On top of that they dare to sell a season pass for future DLC, ubisoft, never again, no trust, no pity, no love.

reviewText:
Let's start by saying that the R6 series has been amazing, and it's evolution has been a blast to play through over the years. Unfortunately, R6 Siege has been a rather downward turn for the series.

The gameplay is straight 10/10. The tactical feel and life or death situational choices really hit hard when you're in the zone  and making every second count. It's a first-of-it's-kind kind of game, in the sense of how the gameplay is executed. I can't exaggerate when I say the game is overtly addicting, every aspect of the gameplay is intense as well as encompassing.

However, there are two fatal flaws in R6 Siege.

1.) The lack of Campaign.

I don't care who you are, everybody loves a good story, and for $60, I expect some kind of story, or atleast build-up campaign. The lack of any sort of campaign whatsoever gives this game, for me, an automatic 6/10 rating, simply because a $60 price tag should include a campaign.

2.) The horrible netcode, and unreal waiting times for matches is utter bs.

Multiplayer is fine, but terrorist hunt matchmaking is completely trashed atm. I have not been able to find a single game since mid December due to 20+ minute wait times for games, all of which last 10minutes max.

The netcode is poorly written, and apparently not a big deal to the devs. There are a plethora of videos on Youtube showing how people shoot INTO walls, and KILL people standing ADJACENT to, or simply NEAR the wall, not BEHIND or INFRONT of said wall. It's a bad joke. When a game is built off being a tactical shooter, and one of which bullets can kill in 1-2 shots on average, the netcode can not be sloppy, and that's exactly what it is: sloppy.

Overall, the gameplay is amazing, but the lack of campaign, ridiculous wait times for matches, and poorly written netcode destroy the fun that is here to be had. The game should not cost $60, maybe half at best, and the bugs need to be fixed if this game is to last until The Division, which is what this game was made for - a money grab for The Division.

Overall rating: 4/10  -- Would not recommend to a friend, unless he had excess money to -waste-.

reviewText:
Since I am bored, I am going to write a long, full review of this game.

Overall, this game has a fantastic concept that is (or soon will be) trashed by greedy money grabbing tactics and horrible severs.

When you start up the game, you have 3 options.

1. Missions that are pretty much just tutorials to help newbies understand the game mechanics.
2. The cancerous Terrorist Hunt Mode
3. Multiplayer

The tutorial missions are fine as they are in my opinion, although some seem a bit too difficult especially since the majority of people that play those missions are people fairly new to the game.

Anyways, on to the actual gameplay!

MULTIPLAYER

This is basically what 99% of the game is, or at least what is focused on, so you would expect it to be flawless, right?

Haha, yea...

You join the queue to get into a match. The recommended time is 30-50 seconds. That seems pretty amazing, but no..

Everyone get's into the match and gets to pick the operator of their choice. Everything goes smoothly. But every single time.. there is always that one guy that is playing on a potato with bent paper clips sticking out of it trying to pick up the signal from his 1 KB/s internet plan. The game takes 5 minutes just to start. This gets super frustrating considering each round only lasts 2 minutes on average.

PROS:

+The multiplayer has lot's of content, fully destructive maps and intense fire fights.
+Killing enemies is difficult and satisfying.
+Literally no match is the same.

CONS:

-Uplay

-Potato servers that make everyone lag and sometimes causes players to get disconnected

-Godawful netcode (What's that? You shot that guy in the head 17 times and saw blood go everywhere!? He still has 67 health, even though 1 headshot counts as a death)

-Cheaters everywhere. I shoot a guy 15 times and then it says he has full health.

-Frost's shotgun

-Lag is insane

You'll be eyeing a corner, making the best choke point the world has ever seen. You are so focused that even if someone appears for just 1 microsecond, you'll be able to get them.
BAM, you're dead!

You're extremely confused on what just happened. Did someone get behind you? The killcam comes on and you see that the guy came around the corner and was standing right in the open for 5 seconds, and shot you. The lag caused you to not even see him appear! FANTASTIC!
(And no, my internet is fine. Thanks for not asking)

-The level 3 guy that has no idea what he's doing and ends up shooting the hostage point blank with a shotgun because logic.

-Buck is severely underpowered. The skeleton key is weak, and his assualt rifle recoils so much you can barely shoot anything.

-You'll be put in a match against fully cooridinated teams that are basically level 150 that will wreck you every single time.

-When you spawn as the attackers, take 5 steps to the left, and get sniped from a window.

-Defenders that jump out of the building and start shooting at you 15 seconds into the match.

-Lack of customization. Each operator has around 2 guns they can pick from, and 9/10 times one gun is 100x times better than the other so there's really no point in choosing.

-25,000 renown for the latest operators that you can get if you buy the season pass. What does this mean? Are the next operators going to be 50K, 100K? Don't force people to buy your season pass.
(Keep in mind that even 25K is a bit high considering you only get like 200 renown a match).


Okay, yea.. playing multiplayer on this game is just going to leave you feeling unsatisfied. Don't get me wrong, there are a lot of epic moments that happen, but it's severely outweighed by the all the previously listen bad things.

Time to review the.. ugh..

TERRORIST HUNT

Choose to play alone or with a team, with 3 different difficulties. The harder the difficulty, the smarter the AI.

PROS:

+It's fun.. I guess..
+Good for warming up before going into multiplayer matches

CONS:

-It sucks

-Suicide bombers
In a game where a couple well-placed shots means instant death, these bombers are a pain in the ♥♥♥. You'll be cautiously scoping a hallway, when a bomber appears and starts sprinting towards you. You put an entire magazine of ammo into his chest, but it doesn't do anything. He then goes boom-boom in your face, causing you to lose.

There are so many cons about it that I'm too lazy to list them all.

FINAL VERDICT:

5/10 if you're a casual lonely player like me. Probably an 7 or 8/10 if you got an actual squad to play with.

I'll update this as the new content slides in and more patches get released. I have faith considering they are aware the servers are crap and they are fixing bugs, like the invisible Kapkan laser exploit.

reviewText:
I'll start this review off by saying that this game is excellent, superb even, when it actually works.

The problem is, well, the game has problems.

The biggest problem for me, personally, has been the constant crashing to desktop due to graphics card driver failure.  At first, I figured that it was a problem on my end, so I took to the Ubisoft support forums to try to figure out what to do.  Ubisoft proceeded to do next to nothing.  I got one reply that asked me to do a clean install of the Microsoft .NET framework, which I did.  When that didn't work, I took to the same forum and explained that my problem persisted and never got another reply from any Ubisoft employees.  They just straight ignored my problem.  Too busy creating weapon skins for microtransactions I guess, but I digress.... Anyway, I tried a variety of other fixes on my own including doing a clean install of my graphics card drivers and disabling my SLI (my laptop runs two NVIDIA GeForce 750Ms in SLI configuration) but that still didn't work.  After awhile, I looked at the system requirements page and found out that, despite the fact that NVIDIA loudly and proudly displays their logo in the games opening sequence, they actually don't provide support for laptop video cards.  I'll own up to the fact that I did not check the fine print about exactly which cards are supposed to work, but when I looked at the minimum requirements for a game and found that my graphics cards are two generations newer than the minimum requirements and in SLI configuration?  You'd think you'd be able to at least run the game without crashing.  If you plan on running the game with a laptop, be very careful.  It'll work without a hitch for hours sometimes, but at other times you'll crash literally every single round of a match.

Another problem the game has is the matchmaking system.  It's always had it's quirks, but recently it has been ridiculous.  I'll admit that I am not a very good player. My kill/death ratio is around .6 and my win/loss ratio is about .8.  But that is exactly why I prefer to play ranked, believe it or not.  The reason I prefer to play ranked it because, when it does work, it works absolutely beautifully.  When you get two evenly ranked teams of players (even bad ones) this game turns into a pulse pounding thrill ride the likes of which leave your hands literally shaking from the excitement and drama of the down to wire, kill being traded for kill match.  What sucks though, is that, generally speaking, this simply doesn't happen.  The matchmaking system just plain doesn't work.  Usually (I'd say something like 60% of the time) the match is grossly one-sided with one team being composed entirely of gold-ranked superstars and the other one being composed entirely of bronze-ranked noobs like myself (and yes, there is an entire rank, silver, in between bronze and gold).  Of course, I don't have to tell you how this type of match ends, the noobs get absolutely stomped.  We're talking noob team gets zero kills and is eliminated every single round.  Furthermore, Ubisoft recently made a rule that players have to play 10 ranked matches in order to have their rank determined, regardless of kill/death or win/loss ratio.  What this leads to is ranked people like me playing alongside unranked" people with kill/death and win/loss ratios of 2 or greater.  I'll admit
date: this is kind of fun when someone like that ends up on your team
recommended: but it's in no way fair to the good player who has to schlepp with we unworthy or to the enemy team who gets glacked with repeated headshots with no real good way to defend themselves.\n\nFinally
hoursPlayed: the game just plain lacks functionality in some areas.  This is stuff I really wouldn't expect if it hadn't been integrated into previous rainbow six games
voteText: but the fact that if you have a suppressor or laser on your weapon then they are stuck there
helpfulPercent: is annoying and immersion breaking at best and a deadly disadvantage at worst.  Enemy players can see your laser which makes it more of a liability than an asset in most situations and having a suppressor decreases your damage output so there is no reason to have it on when the enemy knows where you are.  Also
votesHelpful: if you are playing terrorist hunt alone with some friends
votesTotal: the lobby is always on a timer.  This means that if you are trying to experiment with your loadout you only have 30 seconds to do it before the game will shove you out the door.  I understand why this was implemented in multiplayer
votesFunny: but when you're playing with your friends against AI
commentsCount: why put the players under that kind of stress?  Furthermore
column16: until recently
column17: it wasn't even possible to choose whether or not you wanted a laser or suppressor on your gun in the lobby.  You had to completely leave the match
column18: go to the operators screen
column19: navigate to the gun you wanted to change
column20: and then decide what attachments you wanted your weapon to have
column21: again
column22: regardless of what situation you will be in while you're in the match.\n\nOverall
column23: this game is excellent
column24: truly excellent
column25: when it works.  But realistically speaking?  Between the less than helpful support staff
column26: the very bad matchmaking
column27: and the plethora of poor game design choices? I think most people will find their money better spent elsewhere."

reviewText: For today most realistic shooter with tactical elements & with realistic I mean game without automatic health recovery system & without fictional weapons & gear (like laser weapons, nano-suits & similar crap things). If you're fan of arcade & non-serious shooters like COD, you won't like it & don't waste your money on it. But if you seek tactical slow paced team-based game, if you like special forces & special operations with missions like rescuing hostage or securing the area & etc, than this game is for you. You must be smart, play slow/steady tactically & work with your team. Also another good thing with this game is, that it gets updated regularly. Personally I think, this is the best & only game in this genre since SWAT4.\n\nHighly recommended from me 10/10.

reviewText:
I bought a Starters Edition of this game for 15€

You get pretty much whole content for these 15€ except it's harder to unlock Operators (aka Classes). But I don't mind because this game is great. There are lots of different classes to choose from and each of them has special ability. Most of the objects in this game are breakable which makes a lot of fun! Thumbs up anyway! I really enjoy playing it. It will get better over time hopefully :).

Btw, it will be available for 15€ only until June 19th so get a cheap copy now if you don't care about difficulty to unlock Operators.

reviewText:
I don't really do reviews, but I wanted to do this review like a few weeks ago, but was too lazy so here's the rundown I'm going be giving this game now.

I might be pretty biased of my opinion of this game since I'm in love with tactical shooters and games with no respawns in general, but I have to say this game is pretty amazing...despite all the bad stuff.

First off I'll start with the pros of this game...

+ There are NO respawns whatsoever. This is a round based game; you die in a round, you STAY dead for the rest of the round. Which means any little mistakes you make are on you or your team. You have to THINK and PREDICT where the enemies are coming from. Everything matters and counts. You have to correct your mistakes for the upcoming rounds and think about what you did wrong and what you should NOT do the next time.

+ Probably the best sounding game ever. The sounds are godlike in this game. No game has a sound and audio team like Six Siege's. The sound propagation is used so well in this game.  You can literally hear water leaking, walls crackling apart, gun sounds ricocheting through rooms, and stuff like debris falling onto the floor even if you're below one floor of it. Which obviously makes listening to footsteps NECESSARY to living in this game. Footsteps can either get you kills or get you KILLED. Seriously the sound design is so good and mindblowing in this game I cannot express how much I love it.

+ Dynamic and well detailed maps. The map design of this game is amazing. Some maps easier and less stressful than others. They all correspond well into making your gameplay different everytime. Every map has a day or night side of it. Personally night maps are always better in general. Especially in this game since daytime can be a hindrance time to time especially with the bright ♥♥♥ sunrays blinding you in this game when you're a defender. Some maps are REALLY big. Bigger than you expect a game like this to have. I guarantee you won't love all the maps because some maps have really annoying areas you just won't like attacking or defending. That's just how it is. The maps are pretty detailed; there's radios you can shoot out to make less noise so you can listen better, well designed trap doors for attackers, beautiful textures on things like paintings and walls, you know stuff like that.

+ Well designed operators with their own personality. Each operator are beautifully textured and well designed with their special abilities. No operator is overpowered and every operator has a counter for one another. It's how well you play with their abilities is how you prosper in this game. Every operator is voiced perfectly well and sound realistic to their character. Operators even have data like age and background story for you to read, which are actually pretty interesting and cool. Especially since we have no real story mode going on. It's always nice to have a little background info for little stuff like that.

+ The community at its prime. Despite all the cheaters and idiots teamkilling for no reason sometimes, you can really find some good and quality teammates that will use as much teamwork as they can to win, which I really love. I swear at times when I wanna log off for the night and get some sleep I end up staying up 3-4 hours just because I found a good and competent team which makes the game REALLY fun. You really don't know how much teamwork makes this game fun. ESPECIALLY if you're on a long winning streak with your team, that just makes you wanna keep playing more; I mean come on, who doesn't love to win?

+ Free future content. I think this may be one of Ubisoft's first games that featured the YOU DONT HAVE TO PAY FOR FUTURE CONTENT" thing. I think The Division is also doing something like that also. I'm really glad that Ubisoft is changing their ways for the future of there games sake. All future maps will be free
date: which is good and would of been stupid if it wasn't because there would've been a big community split and nobody wants to pay for maps in a game like this. All future operators will be able to be bought by in-game currency for a higher price than the original operators in the game. This is great because basically you don't NEED the season pass AT ALL. The season pass is basically a one-week early pass type of thing. Everything except for skins would be available to everyone to use after 1 week after the season pass content release.\n\n+ Ubisoft game support. The amount of work and bugs that Ubisoft has fixed to make the game better is extremely good. For example they recently put there foot down and are going all out against cheaters permabanning them and whatnot. The game was a MESS at launch and in closed/open beta. Most things like the matchmaking which was HORRID in the betas and around launch are fixed for the most part. They even do events that spice up the game a little like for example one of our recent events were called the "No Man Left Behind Event" where you have to keep as much teammates alive per round and if we got to a certain number milestone (which we did)
recommended: they would give us a reknown boost for the whole weekend (which is currently going on right now.) So yeah the team behind this game definitely cares about this game and I don't see the heavy support this game is getting running out anytime soon.\n\nSo I think that's all I'll put for the strong points of this game. There are a little more than that
hoursPlayed:
but really those are the only ones I can really expand upon (plus I don't wanna make this review long and boring.)

Now onto the cons...

- No ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ customization of how you look whatsoever. This game isn't like your previous Rainbow Six games in terms of customization. Nope. Not a single cosmetic difference you can make of how your character looks. I REALLY hate that. Not only because I'm big into cusomization
voteText: but because we play with the same looking operators over and over. I have like what over 200 hours in total (betas included) of this game and sometimes I really do get tired of seeing the same faces over and over again. It's insanity man. The only cosmetic customization in this game are gun skins. That's it. They look really nice
helpfulPercent: but come on really? Just gun skins? Even Call of Duty nowadays have in-depth character customization. This is a $60 AAA game. They could of at least added more for customization other than gun skins.\n\n- You can't add other people... What kind of ♥♥♥♥ing game design is that? Why do I have to go through uPlay and manually type in someones name just to add them??? SO STUPID. I've never seen such terrible social interaction game design such as that. It makes me so mad because I've never seen a game that DOES NOT let you add another person. ESPECIALLY IN A TEAM-BASED GAME LIKE THIS. Remember this is a $60 AAA game. Not an indie game
votesHelpful: yet they lack an adding function other than uPlay...like wow
votesTotal: seriously? One of the stupidest ♥♥♥♥ I've seen in a game.\n\n- You can't buy operators or anything during the planning phase. You have to backout even when you have a full team to the menu screen just to buy another operator/gun/skin. Who made that stupid design decision? Like why? That is another stupid ♥♥♥ design flaw I have ever seen. Literally there is NO reason to make the player unable to buy anything during the planning phase and. It's been asked several times on the Six Siege subreddit
votesFunny:
but Ubisoft won't make it happen for some reason.

- You also can't customize during the planning phase. So you're telling me I can't change anything like my gun sights or skins during the planning phase also? Who the ♥♥♥♥ is making all these terrible game design ideas. EVEN INSURGENCY lets you customize your gun mid-game. It's ridiculous.

Personal rating - 10/10.
But in reality it's a - 7/10."

reviewText:
While Rainbow Sige: Siege has it's fair share of issues, overall it is well worth the price.  It has several server and matchmaking issues, like occasional lag, being shot around corners, glitched loading screens, etc. But I don't think it is game-breaking in any way.

If you are a destruction fanatic like myself, this game is the definition of a destructigasm. The gameplay is solid, from the different Operators, to the varied and destructible environments, to the constantly changing game scenario. No two rounds ever feel the same which is awesome, so good work to Ubisoft for implementing a way to make each round different.

I also appreciate the way that Ubisoft are handling the DLC. There is no need to buy the Season Pass, because all future Operators and maps are for free for everybody! Wait, what? Is this THE Ubisoft we are talking about? Buying the Season Pass allows you to gain early access to this new content, as well as some XP boosts, skins, etc. But thank you to Ubisoft for not dividing the community through DLC. It's all free for everybody, which is exciting and will keep players coming back in the future.

Overall, if you want a tactical, team-based, hardcore shooter with great graphics, solid gameplay, and no shortage of fun, this is the game you are looking for. I'd give it a 8.5/10.

reviewText:
92/100
The greatest tactical shooter I've played since SWAT 4 and Rainbow Six 3.

NOTE: Do not expect this to be a new Rainbow Six game. This game is more of what would happen if you combined SWAT 4 and Rainbow Six 3 and then made it today.

Pros:
Teamplay actually works. (litterally)
Destruction system is new and unique.
Heavily addicting gameplay.
Fun gameplay mechanics. (Gunplay, Equipment, Gadgets)
Unique mechanics for each individual specialist.
All maps are classic SWAT 4 types.Cons:
The netcode/servers need A LOT of fixing. Everything from hitboxes to player location is completely off at most times.
Multiplayer only - No Campaign... kinda.. (Check the spoiler at the bottom for info)
Should not be a full priced game.
There is how ever ONE campaign mission named Article 5" that you unlock after completing all Situation missions. They seemed to have hidden it away to show that they are indeed working on a full campaign. It contains everything everyone wanted from a new singleplayer Rainbow Six game.

P.S. FUZE is fine in hostage. Just dont face his gadget towards the hostage."

The game suffers from many issue's. The major problem is the matchmaking issues. Sometimes you instantly join a match and start playing , sometimes you have to wait for eternity before you get bored and stop trying to find a match. This game has massive potential. If Ubisoft can address all the issues and provide constant updates to this game, i feel this game can deliver and be popular and can maybe be the next best thing in competitive fps shooter environment. reviewText:
Overall Score: 7.75/10
Graphics : 7/10 R6S has some very good graphics, but it's not SW:Battlefront level. The modelling is clean, the colors are vibrant, explosive effects and bullet trails are very well developed, and even add light smoke to the area for a second. It truly adds to the immersion and actually can hinder visibility enough to change the game, even though it barely lasts. The lighting is very nice, but I feel that it's not as good as advertised as above. The game simply doesn't have the level of bloom/Ambient Occlusion that the pictures do. However, shadows are processed very finely. I feel that a better bloom/AO and destructible lights would make this game much prettier, but not necessary at all.

Controls: 8/10 Keyboard controls are actually very fluid, much more than some other FPS games that mix up the crouch/prone/melee buttons. With character mobility, you can walk (ALT), run (W/S), strafe (A/D), sprint (shift+W), crouch (C), prone (V), and most importantly, lean (Q/E). The only thing you can't do is Jump, but you can vault over obstacles. Character mobility is very fluid, and characters even have varying speeds/armor based on their specialties. There are no wonky out-of-reach keys or weird hotkeys at all.

gameplay: 7/10 [h4]general[/h4]
R6S can have some very different gameplay between each round, but whether it's a rush in with guns blazing or a tactical synchronized C4 incursion, one thing is constant: teamwork is required. The health system is fairly realistic while still giving leeway for actual playability. A player can go from full health to dead in a matter of a second if they stay in the open and allow one person to fire on them, and it happens a lot. Where teams start at 5v5, if you have one person less than the other team, it could drastically change the outcome. Cover is required. Stealth is needed. Teamwork is mandatory.

game modesEach game starts as a 5v5 round-based game with an objective:
Hostage Retrieval
Bomb disposal
Secure the AreaIn hostage retrieval, your goal is to either break in, get the hostage, and get them out alive, or to defend the hostage.
In bomb disposal, there are 2 bombs armed, and you either are to diffuse one or protect them.
In Secure the Area, a room is marked and you must gain control by being in the room, or keep the attackers out.

Each game mode is an attack/defense style, and though they are interesting, usually a game will just end as a TDM. There are no respawns for a round, so if all 5 are killed on one team, the others win automatically. The first to win 3 rounds wins the match.

Environment InteractionIn this game, walls and windows are (selectively) destructible. Defenders can reinforce them, but attackers have specialties to get around it (such as thermite charges or long-range wall explosives). Getting a drop on the enemy team can quickly lead to their death in a matter of seconds. The only thing is that sound plays a huge role in this game. Every footstep has a distinguishable sound, heard through floors and walls. Sometimes it's impossible to figure out where it is, sometimes its right by you and you know it. Walking/crouching stops sounds, but makes you a sitting duck. If a defender hears an attacker planting a charge on a wall, they can simply shoot through the wall, disable the bomb, and potentially kill the attacker.

Playable CharactersCurrently, there are 10 attackers and 10 defenders. Each team may have only one of each depending on their team. There are 3 kinds of broad classifications for the characters: Damage, Defense, and Support. Damage classes, such as Tachanka and Kapachka (Spetznaz) provide superior firepower and potential harm to enemies, using turrets, explosive door/window traps, explosives that shoot through walls, etc. Defense classes do one of two things: for defenders, they help, well, defend. Rook can provide body armor, and Castle can put up bulletproof barricades. For attackers, they focus on taking down the defenses, or support shields. Thermite can take down reinforced walls, Ash can take down walls/barricades from a distance, There are 3 shield classes as of now: Fuze, Blitz, and Montaigne. Shields are bulletproof and hard to shoot by, by easily flanked if left open, and only carry a pistol. However, they provide superior defenses for teammates. Support classes will do various things to help the team as a whole. For defenders, Doc can revive downed teammates from a range, or even revive himself.  For attackers, Twitch can remotely disable traps and hurt defenders with a shock drone. The variability in team composition creates unique gaming experiences in every match.

IntelThis is a minute aspect, but important nonetheless. At the beginning of each game, each team knows nothing about the other team. But there is a brief time while defenders reinforce a room that attackers can send drones out to search the map for the enemies and objective. Alternatively, defenders can use surveillance cameras placed around the map to locate and identify attackers. Both drones and cameras are susceptible to damage though, and easily destroyed if found. Knowing the enemy team can greatly increase your chances if you know how to use that knowledge.

Networking/social  This is the only true drawback I see with this game. Ubisoft has slightly improved on networking, but it's still a ways to go. Every now and then when joining a game, you might get locked indefinitely finding a match, or indefinitely loading a game. Sometimes in the character selection screen, both teams are locked up because one person can't load. It truly does get aggravating sometimes, but it's easily manageable. The chat system, however, is horrendous. Each message you type may only have up to 32 total characters. For those unaware, that usually isn't enough for a sentence. However, the voice chat is decent quality, but maybe a little low volume in balancers. I had to drastically turn down other sounds and up my PC volume a lot to hear others, on two computers. Also, there is no direct way to invite your current teammates to a party, or even add them as friends because of Uplay's god-awful social menu. There's also no list for recent players, so if you want to add somebody, either commit their name to memory or add them in the middle of a game. If I had to rate it, networking: 6/10, social: 3/10.

Summary With a largely varying gaming experience based on players and characters they choose, plus intel, maps, objectives, and defensive layouts, this game never ceases to keep you on edge. I strongly recommend a good surround sound headset for this game. It will keep you immersed and better hearing the enemies. With smooth controls, quick-paced combat and antagonizing silences before an attack, this game truly delivers a wonderful gaming experience. The social/networking, though aggravating, are not game-breaking at all.

Content availability: 9/10 Honestly, Ubisoft really has outdone themselves here. They've announced that there will be no paywalls for year one (at least), and there is no pay-to-win. You can buy R6 currency, but it's only used for weapon skins I do believe. I've always been saddened by games like this that use paywalls. All characters are bought with renown, along with weapons, skins, and upgrades such as silencers, scopes, and handles. The only thing I would like to mention is the season pass. It's a little misleading, and feel free to check the reviews on it for more info. Generally, though, the SP is simply aesthetic besides 1-week beta on new operators. I'd rate the SP as a $10-15 offer, but definitely not $30.

reviewText:
+ Reasonably balanced, competitive, tactical
+ Very moody. Great ambient sounds
+ Looks great
+ Destructable walls, dynamic enviroments
+ Detailed maps, much attention to detail
+ Decent weapon and loadout customization

- Gun sounds could be better
- UI may be slightly intrusive for some
- Needs more variety in maps, basically all amount to cqc. Though this is probably intentional
- Shields slightly OP
- No singeplayer
- Low tick

Be cautious, unless you've been really craving for a comptetitive fps experience. As a semi-competitive player, this game easily trumps any other big name fps out right now . It can be intensely competitive, something you just don't really get from the typical twitch reflex triple A fps's(e.g COD, BF, Halo).

About 10 hours of gameplay and every match seems to have a nice variety of intense moments. From the typical; last man standing scenario, to seeing a mortally wounded ally in an adjacent room, contemplating the the risky dash to treat him. I've yet to see if the repetitive cqc combat will ever really feel TOO repetitive.

Sounds are overall great. The ambient sounds, in particular, are very immersive; from static radios to the ambient sounds of a crumbling building- It really really adds to the experience. Though after playing SQUAD(get it, try it), every gun sound I hear is just underwhelming, lol. This game is no exception. But it's by no means bad.

Graphics are great. Lens flare and bloom adds a visceral feel to the combat, though serious players may want to turn those off to optimize vision. Maps are VERY detailed, e.g graffiti, garbage laying around, porno magz, weathering on the walls, etc. The depth of field when aiming down the sights is a nice touch. In general, everything looks, and most important FEELS(optimization)... good/great.

Overall the game is worth every penny if you're a competitive player. Think hard about the purchase  if you're a casual, since you will probably get your butt handed to you and there is no singleplayer for your to delude your skill level.

Since I personally don't care about a singleplayer campaign, my only real complaint is the low tick rate, and server issues. Maybe 2 out of 10 games I get some rubber banding and the occasional d/c. This must be fixed. It's not so bad that it's a deal breaker, though.

8/10, An addicting and visceral fps experience. And if played properly- with a competent team and opponent, it is hands down the best competitive big name fps out right now.

PS. I say 'big name' because there are lesser known fps's out there  that are just simply the true unadulterated fps experience, e.g ShootMania Storm, Quake Live, Project Reality/SQUAD. Play those if you really want to test your skill. Stay away if you're a filthy casual(kidding)- you'd be up against players with over a decade of competitive experience.

reviewText:
A great game that is in need of some more content. More game modes, sprinkle in some more maps, and you’d have a real CoD competitor here. Indeed, it brings in what CoD has lacked; A cooperative multiplayer. Most of my several hours have been dedicated to the Terrorist Hunt game-mode, which I thoroughly enjoy. I’ve met some splendid and playful people as I endeavor to make comical quips at the end of each game. Usually things like “I’m playing by golf rules. Lowest score wins” (If I did poorly).

The game does a good job of ‘feeling’ like older Rainbow Six games. It’s hard to explain but it’s always nice to have a sequel that holds onto its “soul”, if it’s apt to use that word. There’s simply not much to say about how the game functions - It’s a military shooter. Even on Normal mode, you can only take a few hits before going down. Less and less on each difficulty level. The Division this is not - We’re back to the 'realism’ of military shooting. The game mixes it up with each “character” posessing a special ability that affects the playing field. Some of them are of questionable practicality - IQ, one of the only female soldiers, has a shock drone. This is not an RPG, so what’s the point of stunning a man for two seconds when one of your teammates can just turn a corner and gun him down in those two seconds? It saves time just to shoot rather than drive a drone around.

Some reviews compliment the community. In the Co-op, I’d agree.
Unfortunately this melted away immediately as I touched down on PvP, wherein I lost three of the four games. Two of them I was beset upon by slurs and ♥♥♥♥ threats just because I didn’t know everything there is to know about “Doc”, considering I had only played him once or twice. Slurs against me just for the fact that I haven’t played this game for 100+ hours strikes me as a little odd, but I always attribute this behavior to age. We’ll never not have sixteen year olds screaming at us from headsets, it seems.

Other than that particular half of the community I find the game in need of an extra helping of maps and game modes. I played during the free weekend (~7 hours or so of this writing) and I felt like I was just going through the motions after a certain point. The game is rarely not fun (As long as I remained versus AI) but it’s hard to feel like a badass when I go an entire round without seeing a single enemy, and my teammates have already extracted the hostage before I could help in any way.

You may see a handful of negativity on this review, but like anything else it really depends on personal playstyles. If military shooters are your thing, then this is a healthy addition to your Library. If you’re not big on matchmaking or multiplayer, there is even a “Lone Wolf” setting for you to play against AI on any difficulty at your own leisure. Enjoy!

reviewText:

Overall?

+Very well balanced game mechanics
+Outstanding graphics, very well optimized
+Interesting gameplay allows for multiple ways of doing objectives
+Variable playstyle
-Gun skins, DLC, but not pay2win or game breaking
-Some issues with Ubisoft servers
-Rare gamebreaking bugs

Some of them are of questionable practicality - IQ, one of the only female soldiers, has a shock drone. This is not an RPG, so what’s the point of stunning a man for two seconds when one of your teammates can just turn a corner and gun him down in those two seconds? It saves time just to shoot rather than drive a drone around.

Some reviews compliment the community. In the Co-op, I’d agree.
Unfortunately this melted away immediately as I touched down on PvP, wherein I lost three of the four games. Two of them I was beset upon by slurs and ♥♥♥♥ threats just because I didn’t know everything there is to know about “Doc”, considering I had only played him once or twice. Slurs against me just for the fact that I haven’t played this game for 100+ hours strikes me as a little odd, but I always attribute this behavior to age. We’ll never not have sixteen year olds screaming at us from headsets, it seems.

Other than that particular half of the community I find the game in need of an extra helping of maps and game modes. I played during the free weekend (~7 hours or so of this writing) and I felt like I was just going through the motions after a certain point. The game is rarely not fun (As long as I remained versus AI) but it’s hard to feel like a badass when I go an entire round without seeing a single enemy, and my teammates have already extracted the hostage before I could help in any way.

You may see a handful of negativity on this review, but like anything else it really depends on personal playstyles. If military shooters are your thing, then this is a healthy addition to your Library. If you’re not big on matchmaking or multiplayer, there is even a “Lone Wolf” setting for you to play against AI on any difficulty at your own leisure. Enjoy!

reviewText:
Pros:
+Good Shooter
+Good Graphics/Detail
+(Mostly) friendly community when you're not being slapped with CS:GO nut cases
Cons:
-Uplay

-Hacking? (I don't PvP)
-Incomplete

Obvious as it is, this game isn't for everyone. If you're used to recovery features in games like CoD, Halo, and Gears of War, you may struggle with the idea that you can't just wait off bullet damage. If you're used to game moments where you wing it, die, respawn, try again with a different approach, you'll have long embarrasing moments of early dying and watching your team struggle to do everything without you.

If you love tactical options, buy this game (preferrably at a discount). If you love plain shooting, don't bother.

reviewText: Rainbow Six Siege is an amazing game and it's definitely a game changer. In R6S you must use tactics and skill together to outsmart and outplay the enemy team. R6S is a game where you will need a group of 5 friends in order to be successful. Be warned R6S is not a game you want to play like other shooters, no Call of Duty Rambo Killing. I suggest to be successful you sit down and learn each others playstyles in order to be most effective, but I digress. R6S opens a new pathway for shooters with the almost entirely destructable maps, and by making team planning a priority. R6S also has a Terrorist Hunt mode for those who dislike multi-player games. Terrorist Hunt is basically R6S with AI you can choose the difficulty and you can play alone or with others. Overall despite it lacking a campaign which I loved the R6 series for this game is truly amazing and is highly recommended for those who enjoy tactical and FPS games.

reviewText:
This is Ubisoft's best game in a while. Also one of their cheaper ones as far as Ubisoft goes.

Summary Essentially it pits two teams against each other. The Attackers, and the Defenders. The Defenders as you would expect have to secure a variety of things such as hostages, bombs, and biohazard containers. This is done by reinforcing walls, setting up traps and barricades, and of course, you and your squad. The Attackers have to siege the structure and once inside either kill all the defenders, or complete the objective. Additionally you can always play classic terrorist hunt which has been improved on since the last Rainbow Six by adding in more game modes which is a plus.

GameplayStarting out you will find that you get your ♥♥♥ kicked a lot however eventually you will get used to the slower pace of the game and it's high reliance on teamwork. (That is unless you have already played a Rainbow Six game) The guns all feel great and are all generally  well balanced. A big downside however is that there are very few game modes. As previously mentioned there are only three of them. Defuse bomb, extract hostage, and secure biohazard container. Almost 100% of the time it ends up being a deathmatch as completing the objectives are often more difficult then just killing everyone with the exception of biohazard container which involves you just standing in the room with the objective. Other then that there is very little incentive to actually doing the objective. This can make the game a bit stale after a while however I can get past it as Ubisoft does promise more game modes to come.. Thank god.

GraphicsAs usual with Ubisoft games they look fantastic. A problem many people bring up is the glare, and I would agree if it was not for the fact that the maps can vary from day and night. When it is night time the defenders are able to see out the windows fine, and so are the attackers giving them common ground. When it is daylight the attackers are able to see in and the defenders will have a very difficult time seeing out. This forces the defenders to change their gameplay style and let the attackers come to them. If it was always daylight and the attackers always had this advantage than I could kind of see why that would be a problem. The game also runs well. I have a GTX 960 and can run it on medium no problem and the game still looks very nice. You also have the option to download Ultra settings which is pretty neat however will require a very strong graphics card. If you have the power and want a good looking game Rainbow Six: Siege will not disappoint.

VarietyThis game has a abundant amount of classes to choose from each from real CTU's across the world which is cool. They all have a unique ability and are all fairly balanced with the exception of one which Ubisoft really needs to rework. An example is the operator IQ who has the ability to scan for electronics. Although recently IQ has gotten a fairly good buff there are very obvious better choices that will serve a much better use to the team. One thing I really don't like is the fact that they are releasing operators that cost a crazy 25000 in-game currency which is hours upon hours worth of grinding or you can buy Rainbow credits and buy it, or get the season pass and get them that way. If this was free to play, yes of course this would be fine but this is a $70 game and they are making you either pay or go through hours of grinding to get the operator. Just my opinion but it should not cost that much in-game currency. As far as maps go it's not a problem. Some are very well designed, the best so far being the most recent Dust Line map. So pretty well done on this front.

Glaring ProblemsOne large flaw is that the anti-cheat in this game is not very good at all. It's not as bad as The Division, not even close. But it is certainly not one of this game's strong points. Additionally the hit-detection at times. Is unbelievable. A few updates have patched it up a little bit. But it is still a bit wonky at times. Additionaly Ubisoft's servers are terrible. Connectivity issues happen will happen a lot and often times the ping spikes randomly, and it spikes hard when it does. It feels like you're getting sucked into a black hole not an exaggeration. If you do get this game, you will know what I mean when I say it feels like you are getting sucked into a black hole. Another problem is that sometimes the player models are completely ♥♥♥♥ed, one time someone got headshot by someone who was not even facing him. This game also has a fair share of horrible bugs such as people being able to clip through walls. Just recently we lost an entire game due to this bug when I was headshot through a concrete wall.

Should I Get it?Full price? No... On sale? Yes! It is good fun and definitely one of Ubisoft's better titles. I highly recommend you play with friends as communicating with strangers will be a bit harder then communicating with your friends.

reviewText:
This is the first and best MMO I have ever played.



This game is heavily reliant on teamwork so if any of you guys or gals think that this operates like COD or CS;GO, you are terribly wrong. If you think that you can endure 15 bullets to your legs, arms, chest, or back or a shot from a shotgun at close range, you are very very wrong. Do not stray from your team, do not walk through a door without peeking out, and for the love of God do not play as Fuze in a hostage situation.

Now about the community:

-I've seen and heard people talking about the cheating and hacking problems that this game suffers but for me, I have experienced none of that.

-People who play this game. Some players are really kind and are forgiving when you make a mistake(s). But some people act like they're from CS;GO, calling you ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ and other crap.

-Some operators will fit your playstyle. If you like traps, go for Kapkan or Frost. If you like wielding a giant hammer and breaking down walls and windows, get Sledge. Pesky reinforced barriers? Get Thermite. Sniping from the outside? Get Glaz. Like shields? Get Fuze or Montagne (or customize your Recruit).



TL;DR?

Pros:
-Lovely graphics
-OK community
-Breaks from the run and gun norm
-Suspenseful if you're the last surviving player on the team
-Beautiful destruction

Cons:
-Bad Matchmaking
-Some toxic CS;GO players corrupting the game
-Bad team players

Verdict:
9/10
Would get called potato or rock PC again.

reviewText: I have to say that I am very impressed about this game. I bought the Gold Edition of this game when it was on sale. Prior to buying this game I was watching videos about Tom Clancy's Rainbow Six Siege and I decided to try it out. This game reminds me about Tom Clancy's Rainbow Six Vegas series that I played earlier. Tom Clancy's Rainbow Six Siege is harder since there is no auto healing system. However if you play as a doctor you can revive your teammates. My favourite character from this game is Ash who uses a breaching round to destroy walls. If you want more challenge then you should play Terrorist Hunt on Realistic difficulty as a Lone Wolf. The game has never ever crashed for me. At the moment I have Texture settings on medium and all other settings on high. I did not experience lag at all. Sooner or later I will try out the Multiplayer part of the game. The game is really meeting my expectations as a tactical shooter game. I can only recommend it.

reviewText:
Good when it works, great strategy team based game. Playing with a full squad is always recommended. If you must SoloQ there is a 50/50 you're going to get a decent team or headache team. As long as ubi keep updating, balancing and hold this game tight it should last. Only worries are PC player bases, I've gotten $60 worth out of it, but honestly if I wants to compete with CSGO etc it needs to be cheaper.

Season pass is done well it gives access to new operaters a week early and doesn't require you to buy them. So if you want to play the ops early grab season pass, if you don't want to grab it there isn't a worry. Simply wait a week and unlock with R6 Credits or renown (Credits = paid currency, renown = ingame currency)

The R6 credit system is...strange? $8AUD for ~600 which is one decent skin and left over Credits. But really if you want to buy skins youll invest the money.

All DLC is free so no player base splitting.

reviewText:
Amazing gameplay, great sound, good graphics, and a community so clean if it were liquid, you could drink it. Snag it on one of Steam's many sales if the tag is a bit high- same for the season pass. It's a unique game that will really satisfy those of you who are genuinely tired of the more prominent FPS titles.

A little tip, a request of sorts, even: please use the Report Suspicious Behavior function if you EVER suspect a cheater. Don't rage in chat, don't go off and get your own cheats, just report. Report, report, report. Legitimate players won't be affected, so if they're just doing good so be it. Cheaters will get stuffed.

Do your part; make this game one step better.

reviewText:
6.5/10

Pros:
- Innovative gameplay with random starting locations keeping the game fresh and appealing in the long term
- Dynamic destruction makes for interesting strategic advantages
- Placeable barricades and utility equipment adds another layer of strategic depth
- Classes are customizable to a fair degree, gives each operator a distinct edge with a vaiety of weapons and gadgets
- Lots of ways to defend and attack an objective
- Fragging enemies is satisfying and rewarding
- Persistence using stats, ranks and renown to buy upgrades and operators keeps players enticed

Cons:
- Hefty price tag (currently $79.99 CDN)
- Matchmaking makes it sometimes very frustrating to find games
- Tick rate in servers are low enough to make a noticeable difference when engaging targets (may take more rounds than necessary to frag someone, or you may notice that you get killed shortly after entering cover, or that you emptied a mag into a person only to find yourself getting killed in the process)
- Bullet Spongey opponents (especially players using Rook and his armour hand-out)
- Sometimes more wait-time than play-time (waiting for rounds to start, set-up or scouting phase, waiting for players to connect in match-making)
- Small 5vs5 battles are somtimes annoying to the point where the round ends to quick
- Only 3 game modes with a handful of maps currently


Overall Rainbow Six: Siege is an enjoyable game that, if the price tag were a bit lower, I would recommend to most shooter fans.  However with the connection issues, short rounds and lack in content, I find myself usually on the fence with judging this game as either a ton of fun or a giant pain in the d*ck.  Fans who enjoy tactical shooters like Insurgency or Squad will probably find it difficult to appreciate this title beyond a few hundred hours of gameplay where most players better acquainted with the arcade-style shooters like Call of Duty or Battlefield will most likely be responsible for keeping this game alive in the long-term.
voteText: 5 of 7 people (71%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
First Impressions:

This is pretty a pretty cool game, with matches not lasting long and a high degree of team work is needed to win. There are a lot of mechanics to traverse around the environment, as well as destroy that environment. Impressive physics aside, the wide variety of guns feel satisfying to shoot, and there are a lot of gadgets/ gizmos to use to your advantage; whether that be attacking the defending team, or defending the objective in the main game mode.

With great graphics, comes great immersion, as the sound design is what amkes this game immersive. listening to the tiniest sounds could help save your team, or act as crucial support for identifying the whereabouts of the enemy. Strategic planning, good senses and quick reflexes are necessary for this game, so goodbye casual gamers, you probably won't last long.

Only problem is, I have such little play time because I ahve no friends to play with (for the weekend it is free for) and it is less fun because of that. But that's not the game's fault.

reviewText:
I played the beta and my gaming experience was pretty lame. (crappy server, bugs, balance...)
Thanks to a free week-end I got the opportunity to make my mind again, and:
This game is good.

The gameplay is unique, require a good piece of teamwork, as you will hardly win a game alone and the level cap can be pretty competitive. That's a good point.
There's a lot of maps, each one giving lot of opportunity and different method to achieve your goal. Good point too.
I could play the same map over and over as each time it will be different, because the opponent will adapt, and you will as well, to survive and win. In *Rainbow 6 Siege you feel the pressure of the siege, and it's always very cool to breach like a real badass task force.

Damn, then why am I not endorsing this then?
It lacks of content. With 60€ I think you can get yourself far more fun by looking at the steam store.
The solo" part is cleanable in 1 hour. The coop is boring. Except one (not that) hard mission (article 5) but you get only one of this kind. This could have been an addition (maybe like the special operation mode of CoD but with more possibilities?).
Outside of this
date: you can have access to most operators very fast
recommended: and it's easy to end with nothing to buy
hoursPlayed: except those damn last updates operators which are damn expensive if you didn't bought the damn season pass.\n\nBy looking to the low populated community
